column2: Who issues official transcripts and what is required before receiving a diploma?
column3: The University of New Hampshire is a source of intellectual capital for the University, the region, and the nation. The University System is responsible for providing graduate programs that meet state, regional, and national needs and the only one at which doctoral programs are offered. Other units of the University System do offer some master's degree programs.

column2: What is an IA grade?
column3: The grade earned will replace the "IA" once the work has been completed. In the case of doctoral research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR". Prior semester IA grades will remain on the official transcript.

column2: Can I do a dual degree?
column3: The Dual Degrees Degree Requirements are required to include separate majors within the same degree, or a combination of two different degrees. Students who have been admitted to the program may register for a maximum of 12 credits of 800-­level courses prior to completing their bachelor's degree.

column2: Can I appeal a dismissal?
column3: A student who is dissatisfied with the decision reached by the program chairperson will be notified and after review will notify the student of the decision. If the decision to dismiss stands after informal discussions, a student wishing to enter a formal appeal shall follow the procedure outlined below under “Appeals Process.”

column2: How long do I have to complete my master’s degree?
column3: Students must complete at least 26 credit hours (seven courses) of graduate-­level coursework in sociology. In addition, students must complete 6-10 credits of Master's Thesis work.

column2: What is a non-terminal degree?
column3: The degree of doctor of education is a terminal doctoral degree that prepares students for careers in educational leadership. The program curriculum comprises courses in educational policy, law, budget management, research methods, and human resources, as well as a research-based capstone. Requirements for completion of the Ed.D.

column2: Where do I file an intent to graduate?
column3: The University provides information pertaining to the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act of 1974 (the "Buckley Amendment") in the annual student handbook publication, Student Rights, Rules, and Responsibilities.

column2: What is the deadline to file an intent to graduate?
column3: Students who do not file an intent-to-graduate will not have their degree awarded. More information on this process is available on the Graduate School’s website. All degree requirements and coursework must be completed prior to the degree conferral date.

column2: How do I apply to grad school?
column3: Graduates with bachelor's degrees may apply directly to certain doctoral programs, the Graduate School also reserves the right to offer applicants admission at the master's degree level in its place.

column3: The application deadline for admission and financial aid vary by program. These are updated on an annual basis and may be found on each of the program pages. All degree requirements and coursework must be completed prior to the degree conferral date.

column2: Can I take courses without applying?
column3: The admissions committee may offer provisional admission and require that the applicant take certain foundation undergraduate courses prior to beginning the graduate program. Courses may be applied to only one certificate program but may also be applied for a master’s or doctoral degree program at UNH. Students must submit a UNH Transfer Credit Form to request that these courses be applied.

column2: What is the Accelerated Master’s program?
column3: Accelerated Master’s programs offer qualified University of New Hampshire undergraduate students the opportunity to begin graduate coursework in select graduate programs while completing a bachelor’s degree.

column2: Can I defer my admission?
column3: Admissions to UNH are made for a specific term and year in one of the following categories: regular or conditional. Applicants who are in the final year of an undergraduate or, in some cases, a graduate degree program are contingent upon the successful completion of that degree program.

column3: The UNH Graduate Catalog offers a wide range of graduate housing options, including single occupancy rooms and a mini fridge for your personal use.

column2: Does UNH offer student health insurance?
column3: The UNH Student Health Benefits Plan (SHBP) provides comprehensive, student-focused, primary medical care through a team approach. The clinical staff consists of board-certified physicians, nurse practitioners, nurses, and medical assistants who are committed to prevention and holistic care. Primary medical care is provided for a variety of common concerns.

column2: Do I need to register?
column3: Students who wish to pursue a degree program other than the one for which admission was originally granted must complete the appropriate application for a change of degree. This includes students enrolled in UNH master’s programs who intend to pursue the Ph.D. in the same department in which they were admitted for the master's degree.

column2: How many credits can I take?
column3: Students can take up to 12 credits of the Master's Thesis Sociology (SOC) - SOC 899 - Masters Thesi. Students typically complete 6 credits, however, it can be taken up to 10 credits when permitted by the department by petition. Repeat Rule: May be repeated for a maximum of 10 credits.

column2: What is the difference between GRAD 800 and GRAD 900?
column3: Continuing Enrollment Graduate School (GRAD) - GRAD 800 is for Master's students who are in residence and need to be full time but have already completed all course requirements, have previously registered for the maximum number of thesis or project credits. As this grants full-time status, students are also responsible for the full time mandatory fees. Effective Fall 2020, may be taken only once.

column2: What is full time status?
column3: Students on full assistantships are involved in assistantship activities for 20 hours a week during the academic year. The workload for students on stipend only and hourly appointments is specified at the time of appointment.

column2: What financial aid is available?
column3: The University offers a variety of forms of financial assistance to graduate students through the Graduate School and individual departments, most of which are awarded for an academic year commencing in the fall.

column2: Where can I find information about assistantships?
column3: The University provides information pertaining to the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act of 1974 (the "Buckley Amendment") in the annual student handbook. This information may be obtained upon request from the University's Advising and Career Center and is available by university, college, or school to current and prospective students.

column2: How do I withdraw from the program?
column3: Students who formally withdraw and do not register and pay for course credits, research, or continuing enrollment by the appropriate registration deadline, or do not return from an approved leave of absence, will have their degree status discontinued.

column2: Can I change my degree?
column3: Students who wish to pursue a degree program other than the one for which admission was originally granted must complete the appropriate application for a change of degree. This includes students enrolled in UNH master's programs who intend to pursue the Ph.D. in the same department in which they were admitted for the master’s degree.

column2: How long does it typically take to complete the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The M.S. in Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and an Acstone experience (3-9 credits).

column2: When can students in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program begin their capstone experience?
column3: Students in Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) are required to enroll in at least one credit under Capstone Experience: BIOT 891 , BIOT 8.9 , or BIOT 8,89 . The capstone (up to 9 credits) will be designed and approved by your faculty advisor or the internship and co-op coordinator and will be consistent with your career development plans.

column2: What is the purpose of the Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program is based on market analysis and additional industry input to establish graduate-level skill competencies in the areas of protein biochemistry, molecular biology, and cell biology.

column2: Who helps Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) students develop a curriculum plan?
column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) focuses on the application of the biological and biochemical sciences, and particularly genetics, to the preparation of new and enhanced biomedical, industrial, agricultural, and environmental products.

column2: How many total program credits are composed of core, elective, and capstone work in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The capstone (up to 9 credits) will be designed and approved by your faculty advisor or the internship and co-op coordinator. Capstone C will be a 6 month industry placement at 40 hours per week and earn 9 credits.

column2: Can students begin the capstone before completing 9 credits in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Students must attend a mandatory orientation session. Students must submit a special registration form each semester for dual-credit courses and note any DegreeWorks exceptions. Students may defer graduate matriculation for up to one year after earning their bachelor’s degree in most programs.

column2: What core knowledge areas will students master in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) focuses on the application of the biological and biochemical sciences, and particularly genetics, to the preparation of new and enhanced biomedical, industrial, agricultural, and environmental products.

column2: Who is the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) program designed for?
column3: Working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. You will learn the theoretical underpinnings of information security and have opportunities to apply your knowledge and skills to real-world scenarios and authentic project experiences.

column2: How does the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) program provide applied experience?
column3: Designed for working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. You will learn the theoretical underpinnings of information security and have opportunities to apply your knowledge and skills to real-world scenarios and authentic project experiences.

column2: According to the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) requirements page, how many total graduate credits are required for the degree?

column2: Does the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) requirements page describe a capstone or culminating experience?
column3: The Capstone Project Cybersecurity Policy and Risk Management (M.S.) is an online only program, taught over five 8-week terms per academic calendar year. The degree requires a minimum 30 graduate credits made up of nine core courses and culminating with a required capstone experience.

column2: What kind of graduate program is the Information Technology (M.S.) at UNH Manchester?
column3: The MS in Information Technology program is a graduate program in the applied and fast-changing field of Information Technology. The program prepares students for a professional IT or computing-related career and for advanced studies in a computing discipline.

column2: Does the IT (M.S.) program require an internship?
column3: Students are required to enroll in at least 1 credit of Internship Experience upon successful completion of nine credits in the program. COMP 891 , COMP 892 , or COMP 893 may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits. Elective courses can be in various disciplines, including computing (COMP), computer science (CS), business and administration (ADMN), analytics and data science (DATA), and more.

column2: What city sponsors are there for the IT (M.S.) program?
column3: The MS in Information Technology program is offered at the University's urban campus in Manchester, a city that embraces cultural diversity. With support from many business, technology and non-profit organizations who sponsor internships, students integrate authentic professional experiences in their academic coursework early in the program.

COMP 891 , COMP 892 , or COMP 893 may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits. column2: Does the Information Technology (M.S.) program require a final presentation or report?
column3: Technical Presentation and Paper Requirement The objective in requiring the two oral technical presentations is primarily to ensure that students have the opportunity to present in front of a group. The two presentations required must be different; giving the same seminar twice does not count as two presentations.

column2: Do all programs at UNH offer an Accelerated Master’s option?
column3: Accelerated Master’s programs offer qualified University of New Hampshire undergraduate students the opportunity to begin graduate coursework in select graduate programs while completing a bachelor’s degree.

column2: What’s the difference between IA and IC grades for graduate students?
column3: The IA grade is equivalent to a grade of B-­ or higher. The IC grade is the same as an AF grade, which means that a student entering the program will have a B.S. degree in a technical field such as a mathematics, science, or an engineering discipline.

column2: Can I appeal a course grade?
column3: A student who has been dismissed for failure to make required academic progress may, with the permission of the dean of the Graduate School, enroll as a non-degree student in courses in their program pending a final decision on the appeal.

column2: How is a master’s thesis committee formed at UNH?
column3: A master's thesis committee is a committee composed of a regular member of the graduate faculty under whose direction it was written and two other members of the graduated faculty nominated by the department chairperson or graduate program coordinator and appointed by the dean of the Graduate School. The students must prepare a written master’s thesis for submission to their Thesis Committee.

column2: How do I apply for a graduate certificate?
column3: The purpose of graduate certificate programs is to serve the needs of both matriculated and non-degree students interested in developing specific skills and knowledge for personal and/or professional development. Graduate certificate programs are credit-based, taught by regular or associate members of the graduate faculty, and normally aligned with existing graduate education curricula.

column2: Can I defer my admission offer?
column3: Admissions are made for a specific term and year in one of the following categories: regular or conditional. Applicants who are in the final year of an undergraduate or, in some cases, a graduate degree program are contingent upon the successful completion of that degree program.

column2: How many years do I have to finish my master’s?
column3: The Ph.D. must be completed within eight years of matriculation (enrollment after admission) or within seven years if the student entered with a master's degree in the same field.

column2: Where can I find information about graduate housing?
column3: The University provides information pertaining to the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act of 1974 (the "Buckley Amendment") in the annual student handbook. This information may be obtained upon request from the University's Advising and Career Center and is available by university, college, or school to current and prospective students.

column2: How do I submit my thesis?
column3: Applicants who are not admitted, or who are admitted and do not register in the Graduate School, do not have access to their application files. Materials received as part of the application process will not be duplicated for personal use by the applicant or forwarded to a third party.

column2: What are the mandatory fees for graduate assistants?
column3: Graduate assistants are students who provide instructional or administrative support as specified by the appointing department. Graduate part-time lecturers receive a fee waiver for the technology fee during the period of their appointment. Course fees are also covered by the waiver.

column2: How do I apply for financial aid or scholarships?
column3: Several forms of financial assistance are available to graduate students through the Graduate School and individual departments, most of which are awarded for an academic year commencing in the fall. To be eligible for any assistance, the student must first be admitted to the Graduate school.

column2: How do I withdraw from a graduate program?
column3: Students who are applying for readmission are required to pay an application fee plus, if readmitted, any accumulated continuing enrollment fees for the period during which they have been inactive. Students are not guaranteed readmission and may be evaluated in competition with current applicants to the program.

column2: Can I take undergraduate courses as a grad student?
column3: Graduate courses are offered for graduate credit only and therefore are open only to admitted graduate students or non­-degree students with a minimum of a bachelor’s degree. Advanced undergraduate courses are advanced undergraduate courses.

column2: What is the time limit for a Ph.D.?
column3: The Ph.D. must be completed within eight years of matriculation (enrollment after admission) or within seven years if the student entered with a master's degree in the same field.

column2: What is the process for appealing an academic dismissal?
column3: A student who has been dismissed for failing to make required academic progress may, with the permission of the dean of the Graduate School, enroll as a non-degree student in courses in their program pending a final decision on the appeal.

column2: How many transfer credits can be applied to a graduate degree?
column3: Students can request that a maximum of two courses, for up to 8 credits of graduate level coursework, from an accredited institution authorized to grant graduate degrees, be transferred to count toward their graduate program.

column2: Can I take a leave of absence?
column3: Students who, because of extenuating circumstances, are unable to pursue their graduate program may request a leave of absence for a maximum of one calendar year. Such circumstances may include medical reasons, military obligation, family emergencies, or hardship.

column2: What is a guidance committee?
column3: A guidance committee should be appointed by the program faculty as soon as possible after a student has begun study for the Ph.D. degree. The committee assists the student in outlining a program, preparing for the qualifying examination, and administers the examination.

column2: What is the minimum passing grade for graduate students?
column3: A graduate student may petition to take undergraduate courses on a pass/fail basis. Such a petition must be approved by the end of the add period for the term the course is taken.

column2: Can I take a course Pass/Fail?
column3: Graduate courses cannot be taken pass/fail. A graduate student may petition to take undergraduate courses on a pass/ferail basis. Such a petition must be approved by the end of the add period for the term the course is taken.

column2: How do I change my degree?
column3: Students who wish to pursue a degree program other than the one for which admission was originally granted must complete the appropriate application for a change of degree. column2: Can I enroll in more than one degree?
column3: The Graduate School allows UNH students to pursue two degrees at UNH and count credits toward both degrees under the circumstances detailed below. Such credit will be granted only for graded coursework completed with a grade of "B-" or higher. Application of such credit toward a student's program for a second degree is subject to departmental recommendation and approval by the Graduate School.

column2: What is the registration requirement for graduate assistants?
column3: Graduate assistants are required to submit current scores (within five years) from the general test of the Graduate Record Examination. International students must submit TOEFL test scores. IELTS scores are accepted on a case-­by-­case basis, and students must have a minimum score of 6.5.

column3: JTerm is a course that focuses on the application of molecular biology techniques of the isolation, quantitation, detection, analysis, and use of proteins.

column2: What is GRAD 900?
column3: Grad 900 is for Master's students who are in residence and need to be full time but have already completed all course requirements, have previously registered for the maximum number of thesis or project credits. As this grants full-time status, students are also responsible for the full time mandatory fees. Effective Fall 2020, may be taken only once.

column2: How do I sibmity my committee?
column3: During the first semester, the student and advisor jointly select members of a guidance committee. A nomination form must be sent to the graduate school to officially appoint the committee membership. The Dissertation Committee is responsible for administering the dissertation exam.

column2: What is the difference between an IA and an IC grade?
column3: The grade earned will replace the grade once the work has been completed. In the case of doctoral research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR". Prior semester "IA" grades will remain on the official transcript.

column2: What GPA do graduate students need to be eligible for graduation?
column3: Graduate students must have a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher in order to graduate.  Prescriptive Analytics Graduation - Degree Conferral All degree requirements and coursework must be completed prior to the degree conferral date.

column2: How many credits below B- lead to dismissal from the Graduate School?
column3: Academic Standards Academic Standards Graduate students receiving grades below "B-­" in 9 or more credits , including undergraduate courses taken while a graduate student, will be dismissed from the Graduate School.

column2: What happens if an accelerated master’s student earns below B- in a graduate course while in dual status?
column3: The Graduate School allows UNH students to pursue two degrees at UNH and count credits toward both degrees under the circumstances detailed below. Such credit will be granted only for graded coursework completed with a grade of "B-" or higher. Application of such credit toward a student's program for a second degree is subject to departmental recommendation and approval by the Graduate School.

column2: How many chances do master’s or Ed.S. students get to pass their final exam?
column3: Students are not eligible to receive credit for any more than the maximum number of thesis credits required by the degree and are expected to monitor their registration to ensure that they do not exceed the maximum.  Academic Standards Graduate students will have a maximum of two opportunities to successfully complete final examinations for the master's or Ed.S. degree.

column3: Graduate students admitted on a conditional basis must meet the conditions as stated in the letter of admission in order to remain in the Graduate School.

column2: Can programs set stricter academic standards than the Graduate School?
column3: Students may be dismissed if they accumulate fewer than 9 credits below the "B--" level, and/or fail to make adequate progress in other aspects of their graduate program. Academic Standards Academic Standards Graduate credit is only granted for courses completed with a grade of B-­ or higher.

column3: Generally, dismissed students will not be able to continue in classes pending the outcome of the appeal, but the program chairperson may make a final decision regarding if the student can continue in the program pending an appellate review or continue with conditions.

column2: Who recommends and who decides a dismissal for lack of academic progress?
column3: A department chairperson or a graduate program coordinator, upon the recommendation of the appropriate faculty committee, may recommend dismissal for a student who is failing to make required academic progress in their program. This recommendation shall be forwarded in writing to the associate dean of the Graduate School with a copy to the affected student.

column2: What are the residency requirements for the Ph.D.?
column3: A minimum of three academic years of graduate study is required for the Ph.D. degree. Resident graduate work done at other universities may be counted toward the minimum requirement upon approval of the guidance committee and the Graduate School, but one full academic year must be in residence at the University of New Hampshire.

column2: What is Doctoral Research (999) and when must Ph.D. students register for it?
column3: Ph.D. students at candidacy must register for 999 each semester during the academic year, even if the minimum requirement has been met. Although Doctoral Research (999) is 0 credits, it grants full-time student status.

column2: When is a Ph.D. student advanced to candidacy and what form is required?
column3: A Ph.D. student is advanced to candidacy for the degree by the dean of the Graduate School upon recommendation of the graduate program coordinator after the student has passed the qualifying examination, met the language or proficiency requirements as are deemed desirable by the student's program, declared a topic for dissertation research, and fully formed their doctoral dissertation committee.

column2: What are the key rules for the Accelerated Master’s program?
column3: Students admitted to the accelerated master's program must attend an orientation/advising meeting to accept their offer of admission and maintain a grade­-point average of 3.20 throughout their senior year, complete their undergraduate degree as planned, and pass graduate courses taken for credit with a Grade of B­- or better (some programs have stricter requirements).

column2: What does an AF grade mean?
column3: An "AF" grade is considered the same as an "F" grade, which is maintained on the official student record and included in the grade point average (GPA).

column2: When is a CR grade used?
column3: The grade earned will replace the "IA" once the work has been completed. In the case of doctoral research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR".

column2: What does an AU grade mean?
column3: The grade earned will replace the IA once the work has been completed. In the case of doctoral research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR". Prior semester "IA" grades will remain on the official transcript.

column3: Students are not guaranteed readmission and may be evaluated in competition with current applicants to the program.

column2: What happens when a graduate course is repeated?
column3: The course may only be repeated once. Only repeated courses taken at UNH will alter the cumulative grade-­point average. Failing a required course for a second time is grounds for dismissal.

column2: How many times per year are graduate degrees conferred at UNH?
column3: Graduate degrees are conferred three times per year (September 1, December 31, and May) . All students must file an intent-­to-­graduate through Webcat by the appropriate deadline specified on the UNH Academic Calendar . Students who do not file an intention-to-graduate will not have their degree awarded.

column2: What must be completed before the degree conferral date?
column3: Graduation - Degree Conferral All degree requirements and coursework must be completed prior to the degree conferral date. Graduate students must have a cumulative GPA of 3.0 or higher in order to graduate.

column2: Who can participate in the May commencement ceremony?
column3: Doctoral, Master's, Ed.S., and certificate students who earn their degrees in the preceding September and December are invited to participate in commencement ceremonies in May.
column4: ["- Administration (ADMN) - Administration (ADMN) - ADMN 901 - PAUL Assessment of MBA Core Knowledge (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/course-descriptions/admn/#:~:text=Master%27s%2C%20Ed.S.%2C%20and%20certificate%20students%20who%20expect%20to%20complete%20their%20degree%20program%20in%20May%2C%20as%20well%20as%20those%20who%20expect%20to%20complete%20their%20programs%20at%20the%20end)", "- Administration (ADMN) - Administration (ADMN) - ADMN 902 - MBA Internship (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/course-descriptions/admn/#:~:text=Answer%3A%20Graduation%20-%20Commencement%20All%20graduate%20students%20who%20intend%20to%20participate%20in%20the%20May%20ceremony%20must%20register%20to%20attend%20through%20the%20Commencement%20Office.)", "- Administration (ADMN) - Administration (ADMN) - ADMN 901 - PAUL Assessment of MBA Core Knowledge (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/course-descriptions/admn/#:~:text=Answer%3A%20Graduation%20-%20Commencement%20The%20annual%20commencement%20ceremony%20is%20held%20in%20May.)", "- Administration (ADMN) - Administration (ADMN) - ADMN 898 - Topics (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/course-descriptions/admn/#:~:text=Answer%3A%20Graduation%20-%20Commencement%20The%20annual%20commencement%20ceremony%20is%20held%20in%20May.)", "- Graduation - Graduation - Commencement (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/#:~:text=Graduation%20-%20Commencement%20All%20graduate%20students%20who%20intend%20to%20participate%20in%20the%20May%20ceremony%20must%20register%20to%20attend%20through%20the%20Commencement%20Office.)", "- Administration (ADMN) - Administration (ADMN) - ADMN 898 - Topics (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/course-descriptions/admn/)", "- Graduation - Graduation - Commencement (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/graduation/)"]

column2: What must doctoral students do to participate in the May ceremony?
column3: Doctoral students must have completed all requirements for the degree by the published deadlines for May in order to participate in the May ceremony.

column3: Students who intend to participate in the May ceremony must register to attend through the Commencement Office.

column2: What is an IA grade?
column3: The grade earned will replace the "IA" once the work has been completed. In the case of doctoral research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR". Prior semester IA grades will remain on the official transcript.
column4: ["- Administration (ADMN) - Administration (ADMN) - ADMN 845 - Supply Chain Management (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/course-descriptions/admn/#:~:text=Question%3A%20Which%20of%20the%20following%20is%20not%20a%20type%20of%20%22IA%22%20grade%3A%20thesis%20credit%2C%20doctoral%20research%2C%20or%20continuing%3F)", "- Administration (ADMN) - Administration (ADMN) - ADMN 846 - International Financial Management (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/course-descriptions/admn/#:~:text=Question%3A%20What%20is%20the%20difference%20between%20%22IA%22%20and%20%22CR%22%3F)", "- Administration (ADMN) - Administration (ADMN) - ADMN 845 - Supply Chain Management (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/course-descriptions/admn/#:~:text=Question%3A%20What%20is%20the%20difference%20between%20an%20%22IA%22%20grade%20and%20a%20%22CR%22%20grade%3F)", "- Administration (ADMN) - Administration (ADMN) - ADMN 839 - Applied Financial Modeling and Analytics - View Course Learning Outcomes (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/course-descriptions/admn/#:~:text=Question%3A%20What%20grade%20is%20assigned%20for%20failure%20to%20either%20drop%20or%20complete%20a%20course%3F)", "- Administration (ADMN) - Administration (ADMN) - ADMN 840 - International Business (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/course-descriptions/admn/#:~:text=Question%3A%20What%20is%20the%20difference%20between%20an%20%22AU%22%20grade%20and%20a%20%22C%22%20grade%3F)", "- Administration (ADMN) - Administration (ADMN) - ADMN 839 - Applied Financial Modeling and Analytics - View Course Learning Outcomes (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/course-descriptions/admn/)", "- Administration (ADMN) - Administration (ADMN) - ADMN 840 - International Business (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/course-descriptions/admn/)"]

column2: Can I do a dual degree?
column3: Dual degrees will NOT be awarded retroactively.  International Accounting Degree Requirements - Dual Degrees If a student's tuition is funded by one or more units, it is up to the funding unit to decide if tuition may cover courses taken solely for completion of the second program.

column2: Can I appeal a dismissal?
column3: A student must submit a letter and any supporting documents to the program chairperson and the dean of the Graduate School within ten (10) business days of the dismissal notification. The appeal should refer specifically to the grounds of the original decision in making this appeal and provide reference to relevant policy where applicable.
column4: ["- Academic Standards - Academic Standards - Policy and Procedure for Program Dismissals - Appeals Process (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/#:~:text=Question%3A%20What%20is%20the%20name%20of%20the%20process%20that%20a%20student%20can%20use%20to%20appeal%20a%20dismissal%3F)", "- Academic Standards - Academic Standards - Policy and Procedure for Program Dismissals - Appeals Process (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/#:~:text=Question%3A%20What%20should%20a%20student%20do%20if%20they%20want%20to%20appeal%20a%20dismissal%3F)", "- Attendance - Attendance (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/attendance/#:~:text=Question%3A%20How%20does%20a%20student%20appeal%20a%20dismissal%3F)", "- Attendance - Attendance (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/attendance/#:~:text=Question%3A%20How%20long%20does%20it%20take%20to%20appeal%20a%20dismissal%3F)", "- Academic Standards - Academic Standards - Policy and Procedure for Program Dismissals - Appeals Process (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/#:~:text=Question%3A%20If%20a%20student%20wishes%20to%20enter%20a%20formal%20appeal%2C%20what%20should%20they%20do%3F)", "- Attendance - Attendance (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/attendance/)", "- Academic Standards - Academic Standards - Policy and Procedure for Program Dismissals - Appeals Process (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/)"]

column2: How do I reach degree candidacy?
column3: If the doctoral candidacy form is received before the final day to register for the current semester, then candidacy shall be effective at the start of the following semester. Candidacy will not be backdated.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Dual Degrees (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Question%3A%20How%20long%20is%20the%20time%20period%20for%20a%20Ph.D.)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Certificate Programs - Tuition (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Question%3A%20If%20the%20doctoral%20candidacy%20form%20is%20received%20before%20the%20final%20day%20to%20register%20for%20the%20current%20semester%2C%20then%20candidacy%20shall%20be%3F)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Dual Degrees (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Answer%3A%20Degree%20Requirements%20-%20Ph.D.)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Candidacy (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Degree%20Requirements%20-%20Ph.D.)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Dual Degrees (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Candidacy (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: How long do I have to complete my master’s degree?
column3: A Ph.D. student must be completed within eight years of matriculation (enrollment after admission) or within seven years if the student entered with a master's degree in the same field. Years on leave do not count toward the time limit.
column4: ["- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Examinations (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Question%3A%20How%20long%20is%20the%20time%20limit%20for%20a%20master%27s%20degree%3F)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Examinations (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Answer%3A%20Degree%20Requirements%20-%20Master%27s%20Time%20Limit%20All%20graduate%20work%20for%20any%20master%27s%20degree%20must%20normally%20be%20completed%20within%20four%20years%20from%20the%20date%20of)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Question%3A%20How%20long%20does%20it%20take%20to%20complete%20a%20Ph.D.%3F)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Question%3A%20How%20long%20does%20it%20take%20to%20get%20a%20master%27s%20degree%3F)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Question%3A%20How%20long%20does%20it%20take%20to%20get%20a%20Ph.D.%3F)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)"]

column2: Do I need RCR training?
column3: The Graduate Council has mandated that all incoming Ph.D. students complete RCR training approved by the Graduate School by the end of their first semester. For more information, visit the RCR website .

column2: What is a non-terminal degree?
column3: Students with the approval of their department may petition to earn a non-terminal master's degree while completing the Ph.D. degree. Students must complete the Master's Degree Requirements for their particular program as noted in the Graduate Catalog.
column4: ["- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Question%3A%20What%20is%20a%20non-terminal%20master%27s%20degree%3F)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Question%3A%20What%20does%20the%20%22Non-Terminal%20Master%27s%20Degree%22%20mean%3F)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Question%3A%20What%20is%20the%20difference%20between%20a%20Master%27s%20Degree%20and%20a%20Non-Terminal%20Master%27s%20Degree%3F)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Question%3A%20What%20are%20the%20requirements%20for%20a%20non-terminal%20master%27s%20degree%3F)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Master's Degree Requirements - Non-Terminal Master's Degrees (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Degree%20Requirements%20-%20Master%27s%20Degree%20Requirements%20-%20Non-Terminal%20Master%27s%20Degrees%20Ph.D.)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Master's Degree Requirements - Non-Terminal Master's Degrees (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: How many thesis credits do I need to complete for my program?
column3: Students are not eligible to receive credit for any more than the maximum number of thesis credits required by the degree and are expected to monitor their registration to ensure that they do not exceed the maximum. No thesis credit shall be given until the completed thesis has been approved by the thesis committee and accepted by the Graduate School.

column2: What is the Accelerated Master’s program?
column3: Accelerated Master's programs offer qualified University of New Hampshire undergraduate students the opportunity to begin graduate coursework in select graduate programs while completing a bachelor’s degree.

column2: Can I defer my admission?
column3: Applicants who have received approved deferment of their admission can request to have their admission deferred for up to one year. Students who request a deferral, and who are not currently active in another degree program, are responsible for dropping any courses they may be currently enrolled in at the time they request the deferrral.

column2: Does UNH offer student health insurance?
column3: The UNH Student Health Benefits Plan (SHBP) requires full-time degree students that are enrolled in at least one in-person course to have health insurance as a condition of enrollment.

column2: How many credits can I take?
column3: A maximum of 12 credits taken by a student prior to matriculation (internal and external combined) can be applied to a degree program. Transfer credits must be formally approved and appear on the UNH transcript in order for them to count towards the degree requirements.

column2: What is the difference between GRAD 800 and GRAD 900?
column3: Compared to GRAD 800 and GRAD 900 , the GRAD 800 program has a higher enrollment rate than the 900 program .

column2: What is full time status?
column3: Students holding assistantship appointments are also considered full time and must register for a minimum of 6 credits, GRAD 900 Master's Continuing Research , or Doctoral Research (999) each semester.

column2: What financial aid is available?
column3: Several forms of financial assistance are available to graduate students through the Graduate School and individual departments, most of which are awarded for an academic year commencing in the fall. To be eligible for any assistance, the student must first be admitted to the Graduation School.

column2: How do I withdraw from the program?
column3: A student may request to fully withdraw from their graduate degree program during any semester by obtaining a withdrawal form from the Graduate School website. Students who are applying for readmission are required to pay an application fee plus, if readmitted, any accumulated continuing enrollment fees for the period during which they have been inactive.

column2: How long does it typically take to complete the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Students admitted from a UNH Bachelor's degree program can complete the Accelerated Master's program in 12 months depending on the courses completed during their undergraduate program.

column2: How many total credits are required for the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.)?
column3: The M.S. in Biotech:IBMS is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and an Capstone experience (3-9 credits).

column2: What is the credit range for the Capstone Experience in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and an Capstone experience (3-9 credits).

column2: What is the purpose of the Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program will be able to: Form a core expertise in an area (or areas) of biotechnology (and allied fields) selected by the student, sufficient to conduct supervised research or other further work (such as industrial development) in that area.

column3: A minimum of 90 undergraduate credits must be completed prior to enrolling in graduate (800-level) courses. column2: Can students begin the capstone before completing 9 credits in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The capstone will consist of one of the following: Capstone A, a research project in a UNH Manchester faculty member’s research laboratory (typically your Faculty Advisor); Capstone B, an internship or applied research experience in an industry setting (including the student’s current workplace if applicable); or, Capstone C, an industry co-op experience.

column2: What is the Accelerated Master’s Option in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The Accelerated Master’s Option is the option to complete the bachelor’s degree, and then officially matriculate into the master’s or graduate certificate program to finish the remaining required graduate-level coursework.

column2: What capstone expectation exists in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The capstone will consist of one of the following: Capstone A, a research project in a UNH Manchester faculty member’s research laboratory (typically your Faculty Advisor); Capstone B, an internship or applied research experience in an industry setting (including the student’s current workplace if applicable); or, Capstone C , an industry co-op experience.

column2: Who is the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) program designed for?
column3: Working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. You will learn the theoretical underpinnings of information security and have opportunities to apply your knowledge and skills to real-world scenarios and authentic project experiences.

column2: Does the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) requirements page describe a capstone or culminating experience?
column3: The degree requires a minimum 30 graduate credits made up of nine core courses and culminating with a capstone experience. The capstone involves a project custom-designed by each student (in cooperation with an advisor) to address real-world or work-related challenges in cybersecurity.

column2: Where is the Information Technology (M.S.) program offered and what schedule flexibility is there?
column3: The MS in Information Technology program is offered at the University's urban campus in Manchester, a city that embraces cultural diversity. With classes scheduled during the day and in the evening in fall, spring, and summer terms, the program gives students the flexibility to enroll full- or part-time.

column2: What’s the difference between IA and IC grades for graduate students?
column3: The grade earned will replace the "IA" once the work has been completed. In the case of doctoral research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR". Prior semester IA grades will remain on the official transcript.

column2: Can I appeal a course grade?
column3: A final appeal may be made to the dean of the college or school in which the program is offered.  Appeals Process Academic Standards - Policy and Procedure for Program Dismissals If the decision to dismiss stands after informal discussions, a student wishing to enter a formal appeal shall follow the procedure outlined below under “Appeals Process.”

column2: How many courses can I take during January Term (J-Term)?
column3: Online, on-campus, and study-away credit courses are available in a variety of academic disciplines at both the undergraduate and graduate levels. Because of the intensive course of study, students may register for only one course during January Term. For more information, visit https://unh.edu/januaryterm/ .

column2: How is a master’s thesis committee formed at UNH?
column3: A master’s thesis committee is a committee composed of a regular member of the graduate faculty under whose direction it was written and two other members of the graduated faculty nominated by the department chairperson or graduate program coordinator and appointed by the dean of the Graduate School. Students in thesis programs may also be required to pass a final examination.

column2: How do I apply for a graduate certificate?
column3: Graduate certificate programs require the completion of at least 4 graduate courses for a minimum of 12 credits of graduate coursework (800- or 900-level courses) organized in a coherent and logical manner to provide knowledge and expertise relevant to a specific aspect of professional and/or personal development.

column2: Can I defer my admission offer?
column3: Applicants who cannot enroll in the term for which admission was offered may request to have their admission deferred for up to one year. Students who request a deferral, and who are not currently active in another degree program, are responsible for dropping any courses they may be currently enrolled in at the time they request the deferrral.

column2: How many years do I have to finish my master’s?
column3: The Ph.D. must be completed within four years from the date of matriculation (enrollment after admission) or within seven years if the student entered with a master's degree in the same field.

column2: How do I submit my thesis?
column3: Students who are in a thesis program are required to conduct research and prepare a scholarly paper under the guidance of a faculty committee for submission to the Graduate School. Guidelines on the purpose, framework, and process for the thesis should be clearly articulated by each program.

column2: What are the mandatory fees for graduate assistants?
column3: Students holding full-time assistantships are charged 50% of the full time mandatory fees rate. Students appointed as assistants, fellows and lecturers receive a fee waiver for the technology fee during the period of their appointment. Course fees are also covered by the waiver.

column2: How do I apply for financial aid or scholarships?
column3: The application for admission with supporting documents serves as the application for new graduate students for the scholarship and assistantship programs available to them. In other cases, individual departments have their own application forms. Students are advised to contact individual programs for more information about assistantships and scholarships, and any departmental application form.

column2: How do I withdraw from a graduate program?
column3: A student may request to fully withdraw from their graduate degree program during any semester by obtaining a withdrawal form from the Graduate School website. Students who are applying for readmission are required to pay an application fee plus, if readmitted, any accumulated continuing enrollment fees for the period during which they have been inactive.

column2: What is the time limit for a Ph.D.?
column3: A Ph.D. student must be advanced to candidacy within five years after matriculation or within four years if the student entered with a master's degree in the same field. Years on leave do not count toward the time limit.

column2: What is a non-terminal master’s degree?
column3: The University offers master's degree programs in a wide variety of disciplines, which can serve either as professional terminal degrees or as intermediate degrees for those intending to pursue further graduate study.

column2: How many transfer credits can be applied to a graduate degree?
column3: Students may request that a maximum of two courses, for up to 8 credits of graduate level coursework, from an accredited institution authorized to grant graduate degrees, be transferred to count toward their graduate program.

column2: Can I take a leave of absence?
column3: Students who, because of extenuating circumstances, are unable to pursue their graduate program may request a leave of absence for a maximum of one calendar year. Such circumstances may include medical reasons, military obligation, family emergencies, or hardship.

column2: What is a guidance committee?
column3: A guidance committee should be appointed by the program faculty as soon as possible after a student has begun study for the Ph.D. degree. The committee assists the student in outlining a program, preparing for the qualifying examination, and administers the examination.

column3: Graduate courses can be taken pass/fail. A graduate student may petition to take undergraduate courses on a pass/pass basis. Such a petition must be approved by the end of the add period for the term the course is taken.

column2: Can I take a course Pass/Fail?
column3: A graduate student may petition to take undergraduate courses on a pass/fail basis. Such a petition must be approved by the end of the add period for the term the course is taken. Courses at the 700-­level approved for graduate credit cannot be taken for pass or fail.

column3: Students who wish to pursue a degree program other than the one for which admission was originally granted must complete the appropriate application for a change of degree. This includes students enrolled in UNH master's programs who intend to pursue the Ph.D. in the same department in which they were admitted for the Master's degree.

column2: Can I enroll in more than one degree?
column3: A student may apply up to 12 UNH credits earned in a master's degree toward the requirements for a second master’s degree. Completion of degree requirements for the two programs need not be at the same time.

column2: What is JTerm?
column3: The Master of Science in Project Management (MSLM) is a practice-oriented program ideal for managers who want to enhance their ability to plan and lead complex projects, motivate people, and deliver the desired business value associated with the project.

column2: What is GRAD 900?
column3: Master's Continuing Research Graduate School (GRAD) is for master's students who are in residence and need to be full time but have already completed all course requirements, have previously registered for the maximum number of thesis or project credits. As this grants full-time status, students are also responsible for the full time mandatory fees.

column2: How do I sibmity my committee?
column3: A master's thesis must be approved by a committee composed of a regular member of the graduate faculty under whose direction it was written and two other members of the program faculty nominated by the department chairperson or graduate program coordinator and appointed by the dean of the Graduate School.

column2: What is the difference between an IA and an IC grade?
column3: The grade earned will replace the IA once the work has been completed. In the case of doctoral research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR". Prior semester "IA" grades will remain on the official transcript.

column3: Graduate credit is only granted for courses completed with a grade of B-­ or higher. Individual programs may have stricter requirements, and those are published with their degree program requirements.

column2: How many chances do master’s or Ed.S. students get to pass their final exam?

column2: What is the deadline to appeal a dismissal decision?

column2: How many graduate credits are required for a master’s degree at UNH?
column3: A minimum of 30 graduate credits is required for all master’s degrees. Many programs require substantially more than the minimum 30 credits. Individual program requirements are outlined in the program descriptions of this catalog.

column2: What are the residency requirements for the Ph.D.?
column3: A minimum of three academic years of graduate study is required for the Ph.D. degree. Resident graduate work done at other universities may be counted toward the minimum requirement upon approval of the guidance committee and the Graduate School, but one full academic year must be in residence at the University of New Hampshire.

column2: How does an Incomplete (IC) work for graduate courses?
column3: An incomplete grade is assigned with the approval of the instructor for excused unfinished work only.

column3: Students are not guaranteed readmission and may be evaluated in competition with current applicants to the program.

column2: What happens when a graduate course is repeated?
column3: The course may only be repeated once. Only repeated courses taken at UNH will alter the cumulative grade-­point average. Failing a required course for a second time is grounds for dismissal.
column4: ["- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Graduate%20Grading%20-%20Grades%20Repeated%20courses%3A%20Repeating%20a%20course%20does%20not%20remove%20the%20original%20course%20or%20grade%20from%20the%20record.)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)"]

column2: How many times per year are graduate degrees conferred at UNH?
column3: Graduate degrees are conferred three times per year (September 1, December 31, and May (date varies) ). All students must file an intent-­to-­graduate through Webcat by the appropriate deadline specified on the UNH Academic Calendar. Students who do not file an intention-to-graduate will not have their degree awarded.

column2: Who issues official transcripts and what is required before receiving a diploma?
column3: A student is required to satisfy University accounts before the Registrar will issue a diploma as evidence of work done at the University.  Admission Admissions - Admission An official final transcript showing final grades and the awarding of the degree must be received by the Graduate School before the student may enroll for the graduate program.

column2: What is an IA grade?
column3: The grade earned will replace the "IA" once the work has been completed. In the case of doctoral research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR". Prior semester IA grades will remain on the official transcript.

column2: Can I do a dual degree?
column3: The Graduate School allows UNH students to pursue two degrees at UNH and count credits toward both degrees under the circumstances detailed below. Such credit will be granted only for graded coursework completed with a grade of "B-" or higher. Application of such credit toward a student's program for a second degree is subject to departmental recommendation and approval by the Graduate School.

column2: Can I appeal a dismissal?
column3: A student must submit a letter and any supporting documents to the program chairperson and the dean of the Graduate School within ten (10) business days of the dismissal notification. The appeal should provide specific evidence, context, or mitigating factors that the student believes should be considered in reviewing the decision.
column4: ["- Academic Standards - Academic Standards - Policy and Procedure for Program Dismissals - Appeals Process (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/#:~:text=Academic%20Standards%20-%20Policy%20and%20Procedure%20for%20Program%20Dismissals%20-%20Appeals%20Process%20To%20appeal%20a%20dismissal%20decision%2C%20a%20student%20must%20submit%20a%20letter%20and%20any)", "- Academic Standards - Academic Standards - Policy and Procedure for Program Dismissals (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/#:~:text=Academic%20Standards%20-%20Policy%20and%20Procedure%20for%20Program%20Dismissals%20If%20the%20decision%20to%20dismiss%20stands%20after%20informal%20discussions%2C%20a%20student%20wishing%20to%20enter%20a)", "- Academic Standards - Academic Standards - Policy and Procedure for Program Dismissals (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/academic-standards/)"]

column2: How do I reach degree candidacy?
column3: A Ph.D. student is advanced to candidacy for the degree by the dean of the Graduate School upon recommendation of the graduate program coordinator after the student has passed the qualifying examination, met the language or proficiency requirements as are deemed desirable by the student's program, declared a topic for dissertation research, and fully formed their doctoral dissertation committee.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Candidacy (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Degree%20Requirements%20-%20Ph.D.)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Candidacy (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=student%20is%20advanced%20to%20candidacy%20for%20the%20degree%20by%20the%20dean%20of%20the%20Graduate%20School%20upon%20recommendation%20of%20the%20graduate%20program%20coordinator%20after%20the%20student)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Candidacy (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: How long do I have to complete my master’s degree?
column3: The time limit for graduate work for any master's degree must normally be completed within four years from the date of matriculation (enrollment following admission) in the program.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Candidacy - Qualifying Examination (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Question%3A%20How%20long%20is%20the%20time%20limit%20for%20a%20master%27s%20degree%3F)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Master's Time Limit (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Degree%20Requirements%20-%20Master%27s%20Time%20Limit%20All%20graduate%20work%20for%20any%20master%27s%20degree%20must%20normally%20be%20completed%20within%20four%20years%20from%20the%20date%20of%20matriculation)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Certificate Programs - CERTIFICATE TIME LIMIT (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Degree%20Requirements%20-%20Certificate%20Programs%20-%20CERTIFICATE%20TIME%20LIMIT%20All%20coursework%20for%20a%20certificate%20must%20be%20completed%20within%203%20years%20from%20the%20date%20of)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Certificate Programs - CERTIFICATE TIME LIMIT (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: How many thesis credits do I need to complete for my program?

column2: Can I take courses without applying?
column3: Non-degree students are not required to register for graduate courses through The Office of Continuing Education. These individuals are designated as "non-degree student" and are not candidates for a graduate degree. Registering for 9 or more credits requires special permission.

column3: Accelerated Master’s programs offer qualified University of New Hampshire undergraduate students the opportunity to begin graduate coursework in select graduate programs while completing a bachelor’s degree.

column2: Can I defer my admission?
column3: Applicants who are denied admission may have their applications reconsidered only if they furnish significant additional material that was not available at the time of the original decision, such as evidence of further academic achievement or more recent and significantly improved test scores.

column2: Does UNH offer student health insurance?
column3: UNH Health & Wellness provides comprehensive, student-focused, primary medical care through a team approach. The clinical staff consists of board-certified physicians, nurse practitioners, nurses, and medical assistants who are committed to prevention and holistic care. Primary medical care is provided for a variety of common concerns.

column2: What is the difference between GRAD 800 and GRAD 900?
column3: Continuing Enrollment (GRAD 800) is for Master's students who are in residence and need to be full time but have already completed all course requirements, have previously registered for the maximum number of thesis or project credits. As this grants full-time status, students are also responsible for the full time mandatory fees.

column2: What is full time status?
column3: Students holding assistantship appointments are also considered full time and must register for a minimum of 6 credits, GRAD 900 Master's Continuing Research , or Doctoral Research (999) each semester.

column2: What financial aid is available?
column3: Students admitted to this program are not eligible for departmental financial aid (e.g. teaching or research assistantships). For information about tuition and fees visit the Student Accounts website .

column3: Students are advised to contact individual programs for more information about assistantships and scholarships, and any departmental application forms.

column2: How do I withdraw from the program?
column3: Students who withdraw, who have their degree status discontinued, or whose time limit has expired and subsequently desire to resume their academic program, are required to apply for readmission. Readmission forms are available at the Graduate School's website.

column2: Can I change my degree?
column3: Students who wish to pursue a degree program other than the one for which admission was originally granted must complete the appropriate application for a change of degree. This includes students enrolled in UNH master's programs who intend to pursue the Ph.D. in the same department in which they were admitted for the master’s degree.

column2: How long does it typically take to complete the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Students admitted from a UNH Bachelor's degree program can complete the Accelerated Master's program in 12 months depending on the courses completed during their undergraduate program.

column2: How many total credits are required for the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.)?
column3: The M.S. in Biotech:IBMS is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and an Capstone experience (3-9 credits).

column2: When can students in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program begin their capstone experience?
column3: The M.S. in Biotech:IBMS is offered in traditional and accelerated formats, each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and the Capstone experience (3-9 credits).

column2: What is the purpose of the Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program will be able to: Form a core expertise in an area (or areas) of biotechnology (and allied fields) selected by the student, sufficient to conduct supervised research or other further work (such as industrial development) in that area.

column2: Who helps Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) students develop a curriculum plan?

column2: Can students begin the capstone before completing 9 credits in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The capstone will consist of one of the following: Capstone A, a research project in a UNH Manchester faculty member’s research laboratory (typically your Faculty Advisor); Capstone B, an internship or applied research experience in an industry setting (including the student’s current workplace if applicable); or, Capstone C, an industry co-op experience.

column2: What is the Accelerated Master’s Option in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The Accelerated Master’s Option is the option to complete the bachelor’s degree, and then officially matriculate into the master’s or graduate certificate program to finish the remaining required graduate-level coursework.

column2: What core knowledge areas will students master in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The Biotechnology:Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program will be able to: Form a core expertise in an area (or areas) of biotechnology (and allied fields) selected by the student, sufficient to conduct supervised research or other further work (such as industrial development) in that area.

column2: What capstone expectation exists in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The capstone will consist of one of the following: Capstone A, a research project in a UNH Manchester faculty member’s research laboratory (typically your Faculty Advisor); Capstone B, an internship or applied research experience in an industry setting (including the student’s current workplace if applicable); or, Capstone C , an industry co-op experience.

column2: In the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program, how many hours of academic work does each credit typically represent?
column3: The M.S. in Biotech:IBMS is offered in traditional and accelerated formats, each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and an industry co-op experience. Capstone C will be a 6 month industry placement at 40 hours per week and earn 9 credits.

column2: Who is the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) program designed for?
column3: Working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. You will learn the theoretical underpinnings of information security and have opportunities to apply your knowledge and skills to real-world scenarios and authentic project experiences.

column2: Where is the Information Technology (M.S.) program offered and what schedule flexibility is there?
column3: The MS in Information Technology program is offered at the University's urban campus in Manchester, a city that embraces cultural diversity. With classes scheduled during the day and in the evening in fall, spring, and summer terms, the program gives students the flexibility to enroll full- or part-time.

column2: How does the Information Technology (M.S.) support students’ schedules?
column3: The MS in Information Technology program is a professional graduate program in the applied and fast-changing field of Information Technology. The program prepares students for a career in IT or computing-related career and for advanced studies in a computing discipline.

column2: How many credits can I take for dual credit in the Accelerated Master’s program?
column3: The Accelerated Master's Program offers a maximum of 12 credits of 800­-level courses prior to completing their bachelor's degree. Such courses may, upon recommendation of the department and approval of the Graduate School, count toward both a bachelor’s and master’s degree (12 credit maximum) or graduate certificate program (8 credit maximum).

column3: The IA grade is the equivalent of the IC grade.

column2: Can I appeal a course grade?
column3: A student must submit a letter and any supporting documents to the program chairperson and the dean of the Graduate School within ten (10) business days of the dismissal notification. The appeal should provide specific evidence, context, or mitigating factors that the student believes should be considered in reviewing the decision.

column2: How is a master’s thesis committee formed at UNH?
column3: A master’s thesis committee is a committee composed of a regular member of the graduate faculty under whose direction it was written and two other members of the graduated faculty nominated by the department chairperson or graduate program coordinator and appointed by the dean of the Graduate School.

column2: Can I defer my admission offer?
column3: Applicants who have received approved deferment of their admission may have their applications reconsidered only if they furnish significant additional material that was not available at the time of the original decision, such as evidence of further academic achievement or more recent and significantly improved test scores.

column2: How do I submit my thesis?
column3: Students who are in a thesis program are required to conduct research and prepare a scholarly paper under the guidance of a faculty committee for submission to the Graduate School. Guidelines on the purpose, framework, and process for the thesis should be clearly articulated by each program. Students in thesis programs may also be required to pass a final examination.

column3: Students holding appointments must be enrolled as students in order to hold an appointment during the academic year. column2: How do I apply for financial aid or scholarships?
column3: Students who are full-time may be granted full­- or half-­tuition scholarships for the academic year or semester. These awards provide for waiver of tuition and are subject to the maintenance of a high scholastic record in the Graduate School. Application is made to the student's department or program.

column2: How do I withdraw from a graduate program?
column3: Students who formally withdraw will be required to apply for readmission if they subsequently desire to resume their academic program. Students who are applying for Readmission are required to pay an application fee plus, if readmitted, any accumulated continuing enrollment fees for the period during which they have been inactive.

column2: Can I take undergraduate courses as a grad student?
column3: Graduate courses are offered for graduate credit only and therefore are open only to admitted graduate students or non­-degree students with a minimum of a bachelor’s degree. Graduate Courses Graduate courses The faculty of each graduate program prescribes the courses that make up the degree program.

column2: What is the time limit for a Ph.D.?
column3: The Ph.D. must be completed within eight years of matriculation (enrollment after admission) or within seven years if the student entered with a master's degree in the same field.

column3: Students who do not file an intent-to-graduate will not have their degree awarded. More information on this process is available on the Graduate School’s website .

column3: The decision to dismiss stands after informal discussions, a student wishing to enter a formal appeal shall follow the procedure outlined below under “Appeals Process.”

column2: How many transfer credits can be applied to a graduate degree?
column3: Students may request that a maximum of two courses, for up to 8 credits of graduate level coursework, from an accredited institution authorized to grant graduate degrees, be transferred to count toward their graduate program.

column2: Can I take a leave of absence?
column3: Students who, because of extenuating circumstances, are unable to pursue their graduate program may request a leave of absence for a maximum of one calendar year. Such circumstances may include medical reasons, military obligation, family emergencies, or hardship.

column2: What is RCR training?
column3: The Graduate Council has mandated that all incoming Ph.D. students complete RCR training approved by the Graduate School by the end of their first semester. For more information, visit the RCR website .

column2: What is a guidance committee?
column3: A guidance committee should be appointed by the program faculty as soon as possible after a student has begun study for the Ph.D. degree. The committee assists the student in outlining a program, preparing for the qualifying examination, and administers the examination.

column2: Can I enroll in more than one degree?
column3: The Graduate School allows UNH students to pursue two degrees at UNH and count credits toward both degrees under the circumstances detailed below. Such credit will be granted only for graded coursework completed with a grade of "B-" or higher. Application of such credit toward a student's program for a second degree is subject to departmental recommendation and approval by the Graduate School.

column2: How do I sibmity my committee?
column3: During the first semester, the student and advisor jointly select members of a guidance committee. A nomination form must be sent to the graduate school to officially appoint the committee membership. The Dissertation Committee will have at least 5 members: no more than 3 from any one NSB department, and 2 from other departments within UNH and/or from other doctoral-granting institutions.

column2: What is the difference between an IA and an IC grade?
column3: IA grade is a grade that indicates incomplete in thesis credit, doctoral research, or other continuing courses of more than one semester. The grade earned will replace the "IA" once the work has been completed. In the case of graduate research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR".
