column2: How many chances do master’s or Ed.S. students get to pass their final exam?
column3: Students with fewer than 9 credits below the "B--" level will have a maximum of two opportunities to successfully complete final examinations for the master's or Ed.S. degree.

column2: How many chances do Ph.D. students get to pass qualifying or final exams?
column3: The grading of the qualifying exam includes Pass, Conditional Pass, or No Pass. The student advances to PhD candidacy, officially declaring the intended dissertation topic. Students who receive a No Pass have demonstrated insufficient scientific premise, mastery of lab skills or critical thinking.

column2: What is the deadline to appeal a dismissal decision?
column3: The deadline to appeal a dismissal decision is November 3 , 2017 and the student must submit a letter and any supporting documents to the program chairperson and the dean of the Graduate School within ten (10) business days of the dismissal notification.

column2: Who recommends and who decides a dismissal for lack of academic progress?
column3: A department chairperson or a graduate program coordinator, upon the recommendation of the appropriate faculty committee, may recommend dismissal for a student who is failing to make required academic progress in their program.

column2: Is a capstone required for master’s programs?
column3: Students who are in a thesis program must conduct research and prepare a scholarly paper under the guidance of a faculty committee for submission to the Graduate School. All capstone experiences must be completed by the end of the final examination period of the graduation date for which the degree is to be conferred.

column2: What are the residency requirements for the Ph.D.?
column3: A minimum of three academic years of graduate study is required for the Ph.D. degree. Resident graduate work done at other universities may be counted toward the minimum requirement upon approval of the guidance committee and the Graduate School, but one full academic year must be in residence at the University of New Hampshire.

column2: When is a Ph.D. student advanced to candidacy and what form is required?
column3: A Ph.D. student is advanced to candidacy for the degree by the dean of the Graduate School upon recommendation of the graduate program coordinator after the student has passed the qualifying examination, met the language or proficiency requirements as are deemed desirable by the student's program, declared a topic for dissertation research, and fully formed their doctoral dissertation committee.

column2: What are the key rules for the Accelerated Master’s program?
column3: Students admitted to the accelerated master's program must attend an orientation/advising meeting to accept their offer of admission and maintain a grade­-point average of 3.20 throughout their senior year, complete their undergraduate degree as planned, and pass graduate courses taken for credit with a Grade of B­- or better (some programs have stricter requirements).

column2: What happens when a graduate course is repeated?
column3: The course may only be repeated once. Only repeated courses taken at UNH will alter the cumulative grade-­point average. Failing a required course for a second time is grounds for dismissal.

column2: How many times per year are graduate degrees conferred at UNH?
column3: Graduate degrees are conferred three times per year (September 1, December 31, and May) . The Graduate School allows UNH students to pursue two degrees at UNH and count credits toward both degrees under the circumstances detailed below. Such credit will be granted only for graded coursework completed with a grade of "B-" or higher.

column2: What is an IA grade?
column3: The grade earned will replace the "IA" once the work has been completed. In the case of doctoral research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR".

column2: Can I do a dual degree?
column3: The Graduate School allows UNH students to pursue two degrees at UNH and count credits toward both degrees under the circumstances detailed below. Such credit will be granted only for graded coursework completed with a grade of "B-" or higher. Application of such credit toward a student's program for a second degree is subject to departmental recommendation and approval by the Graduate School.

column2: What is a non-terminal degree?
column3: The degree of doctor of education is a terminal doctoral degree that prepares students for careers in educational leadership. The program curriculum comprises courses in educational policy, law, budget management, research methods, and human resources, as well as a research-based capstone. Requirements for completion of the Ed.D.

column2: How many thesis credits do I need to complete for my program?
column3: The exact number of thesis credits that are required for each degree will be determined by the faculty of the individual programs. Students are not eligible to receive credit for any more than the maximum number of research credits required by the degree and are expected to monitor their registration to ensure that they do not exceed the maximum.

column3: The first step toward applying to the program is to contact a faculty member whose research is in a topic that matches your interest in order to arrange support for your thesis or paper of publishable quality. column2: Can I defer my admission?
column3: Students who are denied admission may have their applications reconsidered only if they furnish significant additional material that was not available at the time of the original decision, such as evidence of further academic achievement or more recent and significantly improved test scores.

column2: Does UNH offer student health insurance?
column3: UNH provides comprehensive, student-focused, primary medical care through a team approach. The clinical staff consists of board-certified physicians, nurse practitioners, nurses, and medical assistants who are committed to prevention and holistic care. Primary medical care is provided for a variety of common concerns.

column2: What is the difference between GRAD 800 and GRAD 900?
column3: Continuing Enrollment (GRAD 800) is for Master's students who are in residence and need to be full time but have already completed all course requirements, have previously registered for the maximum number of thesis or project credits. As this grants full-time status, students are also responsible for the full time mandatory fees.

column2: How do I withdraw from the program?
column3: Students who withdraw, who have their degree status discontinued, or whose time limit has expired and subsequently desire to resume their academic program, are required to apply for readmission. Readmission forms are available at the Graduate School's website.

column2: How long does it typically take to complete the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?

column2: How many total credits are required for the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.)?
column3: The M.S. in Biotech:IBMS is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and an Capstone experience (3-9 credits).

column2: What is the purpose of the Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program will be able to: Form a core expertise in an area (or areas) of biotechnology (and allied fields) selected by the student, sufficient to conduct supervised research or other further work (such as industrial development) in that area.

column2: Can students begin the capstone before completing 9 credits in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The capstone will consist of one of the following: Capstone A , a research project in a UNH Manchester faculty member’s research laboratory (typically your Faculty Advisor); Capstone B, an internship or applied research experience in an industry setting (including the student’s current workplace if applicable); or, Capstone C , an industry co-op experience.

column2: What is the maximum number of elective credits in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) is offered in traditional and accelerated formats, each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and an Capstone experience (3-9 credits).

column2: Who supervises the Capstone Experience in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The capstone will consist of one of the following: Capstone A, a research project in a UNH Manchester faculty member’s research laboratory (typically your Faculty Advisor); Capstone B, an internship or applied research experience in an industry setting (including the student’s current workplace if applicable); or, Capstone C, an industry co-op experience.

column2: What core knowledge areas will students master in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The Biotechnology:Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program will be able to: Form a core expertise in an area (or areas) of biotechnology (and allied fields) selected by the student, sufficient to conduct supervised research or other further work (such as industrial development) in that area.

column2: What capstone expectation exists in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The capstone will consist of one of the following: Capstone A, a research project in a UNH Manchester faculty member’s research laboratory (typically your Faculty Advisor); Capstone B, an internship or applied research experience in an industry setting (including the student’s current workplace if applicable); or, Capstone C, an industry co-op experience.

column2: In the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program, how many hours of academic work does each credit typically represent?
column3: The M.S. in Biotech:IBMS is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and Capstone experience (3-9 credits).

column2: Who is the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) program designed for?
column3: Working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. You will learn the theoretical underpinnings of information security and have opportunities to apply your knowledge and skills to real-world scenarios and authentic project experiences.

column2: Which two computing trends are named in the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) description as drivers of demand?
column3: The M.S. in Cybersecurity Engineering gives you the technical skills and experience to meet that demand, preparing you to secure information, communications, networks and control systems for any organization. From marketing to legal to finance, employees across the industry are more aware of the flow of data and the measures needed to keep it secure.

column2: What kind of theoretical knowledge is paired with practice in the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.)?
column3: Designed for working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. You will learn the theoretical underpinnings of information security and have opportunities to apply your knowledge and skills to real-world scenarios and authentic project experiences.

column2: How does the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) position graduates for organizational impact?
column3: The Cybersecurity Engineering program is able to identify, analyze and respond to the complex information security threats that are increasingly common in today's digital landscape. You'll learn skills in core and advanced information security, preparing you to develop, integrate and evaluate secure IT systems and services for any organization.

column2: According to the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) description, what three actions will students learn regarding secure information systems?
column3: Security is a key component of cybersecurity, and it's important to understand how best practices, standards, and organizational policy can help manage such measures.  Security Measures I Cybersecurity Policy & Risk Management (CPRM) - CPRM 830 - security measures I This course introduces common technological and organizational measures for cybersecurity, with a focus on protection concepts.

column2: Does the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) requirements page describe a capstone or culminating experience?
column3: The Capstone project requires a minimum 30 graduate credits made up of nine core courses and culminating with a required capstone experience. The capstone involves a project custom-designed by each student (in cooperation with an advisor) to address real-world or work-related challenges in cybersecurity.

column2: Where is the Information Technology (M.S.) program offered and what schedule flexibility is there?

column2: Does the IT (M.S.) program require an internship?
column3: Students are required to enroll in at least 1 credit of Internship Experience upon successful completion of nine credits in the program. COMP 891 , COMP 892 , or COMP 893 may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits.

column2: What city sponsors are there for the IT (M.S.) program?
column3: New Hampshire's largest city and the state's corporate and financial center, the program requires an internship experience. column2: Does the Information Technology (M.S.) offer flexibility for part-time students?

column2: How is the Master’s Thesis Option structured in the Information Technology (M.S.) program?
column3: Students who are in a thesis program are required to conduct research and prepare a scholarly paper under the guidance of a faculty committee for submission to the Graduate School. Guidelines on the purpose, framework, and process for the thesis should be clearly articulated by each program. Students in thesis programs may also be required to pass a final examination.

column2: Does the Information Technology (M.S.) curriculum include both coursework and research?
column3: The MS in Information Technology program is a professional graduate program in the applied and fast-changing field of Information Technology. The program prepares students for a career in IT or computing-related career and for advanced studies in a computing discipline.

column2: Is there a specific credit requirement for the internship course in the Information Technology (M.S.) program?
column3: Students are required to enroll in at least 1 credit of Internship Experience upon successful completion of nine credits in the program. COMP 891 , COMP 892 , or COMP 893 may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits.

column2: How many credits can I take for dual credit in the Accelerated Master’s program?
column3: The Accelerated Master's Program offers a maximum of 12 credits of 800-level courses prior to completing their bachelor’s degree. These courses may, upon recommendation of the department and approval of the Graduate School, count toward both a bachelor's and master's degree (12 credit maximum) or graduate certificate program (8 credit maximum).

column2: What’s the difference between IA and IC grades for graduate students?
column3: A grade of B-­ or higher is required for graduate students who have a B.S. degree in a technical field. The grade earned will replace the "IA" once the work has been completed.

column2: Can I appeal a course grade?
column3: A student must submit a letter and any supporting documents to the program chairperson and the dean of the Graduate School within ten (10) business days of the dismissal notification. The appeal should provide specific evidence, context, or mitigating factors that the student believes should be considered in reviewing the decision.

column2: What registration is required for graduate assistants to be considered full time?
column3: Students on full assistantships are involved in assistantship activities for 20 hours a week during the academic year. The workload for students in both of these categories is less than 20 hours per week.

column2: How is a master’s thesis committee formed at UNH?
column3: A master’s thesis committee is a committee composed of a regular member of the graduate faculty under whose direction it was written and two other members of the graduated faculty nominated by the department chairperson or graduate program coordinator and appointed by the dean of the Graduate School.

column2: How do I apply for a graduate certificate?
column3: Graduate certificate programs require the completion of at least 4 graduate courses for a minimum of 12 credits of graduate coursework (800- or 900-level courses) organized in a coherent and logical manner to provide knowledge and expertise relevant to a specific aspect of professional and/or personal development.

column2: How many years do I have to finish my master’s?
column3: Students who earn a bachelor’s degree must be completed within four years from the date of matriculation (enrollment following admission) in the program. Progress toward the degree will be carefully monitored by the advisor and the Graduate School to ensure that adequate advancement is made toward the completion of the program and that any deficiencies noted at the time of admission are removed.

column2: What are the mandatory fees for graduate assistants?
column3: Students holding appointments must be enrolled as students in order to hold an appointment during the academic year. Assistants, fellows or graduate part-­time lecturers must register for a minimum of 6 course/thesis credits, Master's Continuing Research ( GRAD 900 ) or Doctoral Research (999) during each semester in which they hold their appointments.

column2: How do I apply for financial aid or scholarships?
column3: Students who are full-time may be granted full­- or half-­tuition scholarships for the academic year or semester. These awards provide for waiver of tuition and are subject to the maintenance of a high scholastic record in the Graduate School. Application is made to the student's department or program.

column3: Students who withdraw, who have their degree status discontinued, or whose time limit has expired and subsequently desire to resume their academic program, are required to apply for readmission. Readmission forms are available at the Graduate School's website.

column2: Can I take undergraduate courses as a grad student?
column3: A graduate student may petition to take undergraduate courses on a pass/fail basis. Such a petition must be approved by the end of the add period for the term the course is taken.

column2: What is the time limit for a Ph.D.?
column3: The Ph.D. must be completed within eight years of matriculation (enrollment after admission) or within seven years if the student entered with a master's degree in the same field.

column3: Ph.D. students, with the approval of their department, may petition to earn a non-terminal master’s degree while completing the Ph. D.

column3: Students who do not file an intent-to-graduate will not have their degree awarded. More information on this process is available on the Graduate School’s website .

column2: What is the process for appealing an academic dismissal?
column3: A student must submit a letter and supporting documents to the program chairperson and the dean of the Graduate School within ten (10) business days of the dismissal notification. The appeal should provide specific evidence, context, or mitigating factors that the student believes should be considered in reviewing the decision.

column2: How many transfer credits can be applied to a graduate degree?
column3: Students may request that a maximum of two courses, for up to 8 credits of graduate level coursework, from an accredited institution authorized to grant graduate degrees, be transferred to count toward their graduate program.

column2: Can I take a leave of absence?
column3: Unless a leave of absence is granted, graduate students enrolled in face to face programs are required to maintain continuous enrollment each semester of the academic year until their degree is formally awarded by registering for course credits, research, or continuing enrollment.

column2: Can I appeal a grade?
column3: The Dean may call the appeals panel back together or overturn the decision of the panel. In extraordinary circumstances, decisions made by the panel are final and non-reviewable.

column2: Can I enroll in more than one degree?
column3: The Graduate School allows UNH students to pursue two degrees at UNH and count credits toward both degrees under the circumstances detailed below. Such credit will be granted only for graded coursework completed with a grade of "B-" or higher. Application of such credit toward a student's program for a second degree is subject to departmental recommendation and approval by the Graduate School.

column2: How do I sibmity my committee?
column3: During the first semester, the student and advisor jointly select members of a guidance committee. A nomination form must be sent to the graduate school to officially appoint the committee membership. The Dissertation Committee will have at least 5 members: no more than 3 from any one NSB department, and 2 from other departments within UNH and/or from other doctoral-granting institutions.

column2: What is the difference between an IA and an IC grade?
column3: The grade earned will replace the "IA" once the work has been completed. In the case of doctoral research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR".

column2: How many chances do Ph.D. students get to pass qualifying or final exams?
column3: The grading of the qualifying exam includes Pass, Conditional Pass, or No Pass. The student advances to PhD candidacy, officially declaring the intended dissertation topic. column2: What is the deadline to appeal a dismissal decision?

column2: Is a capstone required for master’s programs?
column3: Students who are in a thesis program are required to conduct research and prepare a scholarly paper under the guidance of a faculty committee for submission to the Graduate School. Guidelines on the purpose, framework, and process for the thesis should be clearly articulated by each program.

column2: What are the residency requirements for the Ph.D.?
column3: A minimum of three academic years of graduate study is required for the Ph.D. degree. Resident graduate work done at other universities may be counted toward the minimum requirement upon approval of the guidance committee and the Graduate School, but one full academic year must be in residence at the University of New Hampshire.

column2: When is a Ph.D. student advanced to candidacy and what form is required?
column3: A Ph.D. student is advanced to candidacy for the degree by the dean of the Graduate School upon recommendation of the graduate program coordinator after the student has passed the qualifying examination, met the language or proficiency requirements as are deemed desirable by the student's program, declared a topic for dissertation research, and fully formed their doctoral dissertation committee.

column2: What are the key rules for the Accelerated Master’s program?
column3: Students admitted to the accelerated master's program must attend an orientation/advising meeting to accept their offer of admission and maintain a grade­-point average of 3.20 throughout their senior year, complete their undergraduate degree as planned, and pass graduate courses taken for credit with a Grade of B­- or better (some programs have stricter requirements).

column2: What is the policy on course withdrawal (W) and its impact?
column3: Students who do not formally withdraw and do not register and pay for course credits, research, or continuing enrollment by the appropriate registration deadline, or do not return from an approved leave of absence, will have their degree status discontinued.

column2: What happens when a graduate course is repeated?
column3: The course may only be repeated once. Only repeated courses taken at UNH will alter the cumulative grade-­point average. Failing a required course for a second time is grounds for dismissal.

column2: How many times per year are graduate degrees conferred at UNH?
column3: Graduate degrees are conferred three times per year (September 1, December 31, and May) . The Graduate School allows UNH students to pursue two degrees at UNH and count credits toward both degrees under the circumstances detailed below. Such credit will be granted only for graded coursework completed with a grade of "B-" or higher.

column2: Do I have to file an intent to graduate?
column3: Students who do not file an intent-to-graduate will not have their degree awarded. More information on this process is available on the Graduate School’s website. column3: The annual commencement ceremony is held in May.

column2: Who can participate in the May commencement ceremony?
column3: Graduate students who earn their degrees in the preceding September and December are invited to participate in commencement ceremonies in May. Master's, Ed.S., and certificate students who expect to complete their degree program in May, as well as those who expect completion their programs at the end of the summer term following the commencement ceremony (September).

column2: Who issues official transcripts and what is required before receiving a diploma?
column3: The university partners with Parchment for its online ordering and official transcript production. An official final transcript showing final grades and the awarding of the degree must be received by the Graduate School before the student may enroll for the graduate program.

column2: What is an IA grade?
column3: The grade earned will replace the "IA" once the work has been completed. In the case of doctoral research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR".

column2: Can I do a dual degree?
column3: The Graduate School allows UNH students to pursue two degrees at UNH and count credits toward both degrees under the circumstances detailed below. Such credit will be granted only for graded coursework completed with a grade of "B-" or higher. Application of such credit toward a student's program for a second degree is subject to departmental recommendation and approval by the Graduate School.

column2: Do I need RCR training?
column3: The RCR program is aimed at ensuring that all Ph.D. students complete RCR training approved by the Graduate School by the end of their first semester. For more information, visit the RCR website .

column2: What is a non-terminal degree?
column3: The degree of doctor of education is a terminal doctoral degree that prepares students for careers in educational leadership. The program curriculum comprises courses in educational policy, law, budget management, research methods, and human resources, as well as a research-based capstone. Requirements for completion of the Ed.D.

column2: How many thesis credits do I need to complete for my program?
column3: The exact number of thesis credits that are required for each degree will be determined by the faculty of the individual programs. Students are not eligible to receive credit for any more than the maximum number of research credits required by the degree and are expected to monitor their registration to ensure that they do not exceed the maximum.

column2: How do I apply to grad school?
column3: The first step toward applying to the program is to contact a faculty member whose research is in a topic that matches your interest in order to arrange support for your thesis or paper of publishable quality. Interested students must submit a full graduate application to the graduate school during their junior year.

column2: What is the Accelerated Master’s program?

column2: Can I defer my admission?
column3: Students who are denied admission may have their applications reconsidered only if they furnish significant additional material that was not available at the time of the original decision, such as evidence of further academic achievement or more recent and significantly improved test scores.

column2: Does UNH offer student health insurance?
column3: UNH provides comprehensive, student-focused, primary medical care through a team approach. The clinical staff consists of board-certified physicians, nurse practitioners, nurses, and medical assistants who are committed to prevention and holistic care. Primary medical care is provided for a variety of common concerns.

column2: How many credits can I take?
column3: The Graduate School requires that students complete up to 12 credits at the 800-level during their undergraduate studies, earning dual credit toward their B.S. and M.S degrees. column2: What is the difference between GRAD 800 and GRAD 900?
column3: Continuing Enrollment (GRAD 800) is for Master's students who are in residence and need to be full time but have already completed all course requirements, have previously registered for the maximum number of thesis or project credits. As this grants full-time status, students are also responsible for the full time mandatory fees.

column2: Where can I find information about assistantships?
column3: Students are advised to contact individual programs for more information about assistantships and scholarships, and any departmental application forms.

column2: How do I withdraw from the program?
column3: Students who withdraw, who have their degree status discontinued, or whose time limit has expired and subsequently desire to resume their academic program, are required to apply for readmission. Readmission forms are available at the Graduate School's website.

column2: Can I change my degree?
column3: Students who wish to pursue a degree program other than the one for which admission was originally granted must complete the appropriate application for a change of degree. This includes students enrolled in UNH master's programs who intend to pursue the Ph.D. in the same department in which they were admitted for the master’s degree.
column4: ["- Registration - Registration - Non-registration - Change of Degree (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/#:~:text=What%20does%20a%20student%20need%20to%20do%20in%20order%20to%20change%20their%20degree%3F)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Dual Degrees (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Degree%20Requirements%20-%20Dual%20Degrees%20If%20the%20student%20withdraws%20from%20one%20of%20the%20participating%20programs%2C%20the%20dual-degree%20arrangement%20is%20automatically%20nullified.)", "- Registration - Registration - Non-registration - Change of Degree (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/#:~:text=Registration%20-%20Non-registration%20-%20Change%20of%20Degree%20Students%20who%20wish%20to%20pursue%20a%20degree%20program%20other%20than%20the%20one%20for%20which%20admission%20was%20originally%20granted)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Dual Degrees (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Degree%20Requirements%20-%20Dual%20Degrees%20The%20Graduate%20School%20allows%20UNH%20students%20to%20pursue%20two%20degrees%20at%20UNH%20and%20count%20credits%20toward%20both%20degrees%20under%20the)", "- Credit Transfer - Credit Transfer (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/credit-transfer/#:~:text=Credit%20Transfer%20A%20maximum%20of%2012%20credits%20taken%20by%20a%20student%20prior%20to%20matriculation%20%28internal%20and%20external%20combined%29%20can%20be%20applied%20to%20a%20degree%20program.)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Dual Degrees (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)", "- Credit Transfer - Credit Transfer (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/credit-transfer/)"]

column2: How long does it typically take to complete the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Students admitted from a UNH Bachelor’s degree program can complete the Accelerated Master's program in 12 months depending on the courses completed during their undergraduate program.

column2: How many total credits are required for the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.)?
column3: The M.S. in Biotech:IBMS is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and an Capstone experience (3-9 credits).

column2: What is the purpose of the Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program will be able to: Form a core expertise in an area (or areas) of biotechnology (and allied fields) selected by the student, sufficient to conduct supervised research or other further work (such as industrial development) in that area.

column3: The capstone will consist of one of the following: Capstone A , a research project in a UNH Manchester faculty member’s research laboratory (typically your Faculty Advisor); Capstone B, an internship or applied research experience in an industry setting (including the student’s current workplace if applicable); or, Capstone C , an industry co-op experience.

column2: What is the maximum number of elective credits in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) is offered in traditional and accelerated formats, each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and an Capstone experience (3-9 credits).

column3: Graduate certificate program students: Earn up to 8* graduate (800-level) course credits while completing a bachelor’s degree. This coursework will count as dual-credit toward both the bachelor’'s and master''' degrees.

column2: Who supervises the Capstone Experience in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The capstone will consist of one of the following: Capstone A, a research project in a UNH Manchester faculty member’s research laboratory (typically your Faculty Advisor); Capstone B, an internship or applied research experience in an industry setting (including the student’s current workplace if applicable); or, Capstone C, an industry co-op experience.

column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) - A student successfully completing the biotechnology:Industrial and BioMEDical Sciences program will be able to: Compete effectively for Masters-level employment and for admission to Ph.D. or other graduate programs in their chosen area and be successful in these endeavors.

column2: Does the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program integrate academic and professional preparation?
column3: A student successfully completing the Biotechnology:Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program will be able to: Form a core expertise in an area (or areas) of biotechnology (and allied fields) selected by the student, sufficient to conduct supervised research or other further work (such as industrial development) in that area.

column2: What is the relationship between core courses and elective courses in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The program welcomes you to enroll in courses in other UNH colleges in order to complete your elective requirements. column2: What core knowledge areas will students master in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The Biotechnology:Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program will be able to: Form a core expertise in an area (or areas) of biotechnology (and allied fields) selected by the student, sufficient to conduct supervised research or other further work (such as industrial development) in that area.

column2: What capstone expectation exists in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The capstone will consist of one of the following: Capstone A, a research project in a UNH Manchester faculty member’s research laboratory (typically your Faculty Advisor); Capstone B, an internship or applied research experience in an industry setting (including the student’s current workplace if applicable); or, Capstone C, an industry co-op experience.

column2: In the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program, how many hours of academic work does each credit typically represent?
column3: The M.S. in Biotech:IBMS is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and Capstone experience (3-9 credits).

column2: Who is the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) program designed for?
column3: Working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. You will learn the theoretical underpinnings of information security and have opportunities to apply your knowledge and skills to real-world scenarios and authentic project experiences.

column2: Which two computing trends are named in the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) description as drivers of demand?
column3: The M.S. in Cybersecurity Engineering gives you the technical skills and experience to meet that demand, preparing you to secure information, communications, networks and control systems for any organization. From marketing to legal to finance, employees across the industry are more aware of the flow of data and the measures needed to keep it secure.

column2: What kind of theoretical knowledge is paired with practice in the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.)?
column3: Designed for working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. You will learn the theoretical underpinnings of information security and have opportunities to apply your knowledge and skills to real-world scenarios and authentic project experiences.

column2: How does the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) position graduates for organizational impact?
column3: The Cybersecurity Engineering program is able to identify, analyze and respond to the complex information security threats that are increasingly common in today's digital landscape. You'll learn skills in core and advanced information security, preparing you to develop, integrate and evaluate secure IT systems and services for any organization.

column2: According to the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) description, what three actions will students learn regarding secure information systems?
column3: Security is a key component of cybersecurity, and it's important to understand how best practices, standards, and organizational policy can help manage such measures.  Security Measures I Cybersecurity Policy & Risk Management (CPRM) - CPRM 830 - security measures I This course introduces common technological and organizational measures for cybersecurity, with a focus on protection concepts.

column2: Does the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) requirements page describe a capstone or culminating experience?
column3: The Capstone Project Cybersecurity Policy and Risk Management (M.S.) requires a minimum 30 graduate credits made up of nine core courses and culminating with a required capstone experience. The capstone involves a project custom-designed by each student (in cooperation with an advisor) to address real-world or work-related challenges in cybersecurity.

column2: Does the IT (M.S.) program require an internship?
column3: Students are required to enroll in at least 1 credit of Internship Experience upon successful completion of nine credits in the program. COMP 891 , COMP 892 , or COMP 893 may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits.

column2: What city sponsors are there for the IT (M.S.) program?
column3: New Hampshire's largest city and the state's corporate and financial center, the program requires an internship experience. column2: Does the Information Technology (M.S.) offer flexibility for part-time students?

column2: How is the Master’s Thesis Option structured in the Information Technology (M.S.) program?
column3: Students who are in a thesis program are required to conduct research and prepare a scholarly paper under the guidance of a faculty committee for submission to the Graduate School. Guidelines on the purpose, framework, and process for the thesis should be clearly articulated by each program. Students in thesis programs may also be required to pass a final examination.

column2: Does the Information Technology (M.S.) curriculum include both coursework and research?
column3: The MS in Information Technology program is a professional graduate program in the applied and fast-changing field of Information Technology. The program prepares students for a career in IT or computing-related career and for advanced studies in a computing discipline.

column2: Is there a specific credit requirement for the internship course in the Information Technology (M.S.) program?
column3: Students are required to enroll in at least 1 credit of Internship Experience upon successful completion of nine credits in the program. COMP 891 , COMP 892 , or COMP 893 may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits.

column2: How many credits can I take for dual credit in the Accelerated Master’s program?

column2: What’s the difference between IA and IC grades for graduate students?
column3: A grade of B-­ or higher is required for graduate students who have a B.S. degree in a technical field. The grade earned will replace the "IA" once the work has been completed.

column2: Can I appeal a course grade?
column3: A student must submit a letter and any supporting documents to the program chairperson and the dean of the Graduate School within ten (10) business days of the dismissal notification. The appeal should provide specific evidence, context, or mitigating factors that the student believes should be considered in reviewing the decision.

column2: What registration is required for graduate assistants to be considered full time?

column2: How is a master’s thesis committee formed at UNH?
column3: A master’s thesis committee is a committee composed of a regular member of the graduate faculty under whose direction it was written and two other members of the graduated faculty nominated by the department chairperson or graduate program coordinator and appointed by the dean of the Graduate School.

column2: How do I apply for a graduate certificate?

column2: What are the mandatory fees for graduate assistants?
column3: Students holding appointments must be enrolled as students in order to hold an appointment during the academic year. Assistants, fellows or graduate part-­time lecturers must register for a minimum of 6 course/thesis credits, Master's Continuing Research ( GRAD 900 ) or Doctoral Research (999) during each semester in which they hold their appointments.

column2: How do I apply for financial aid or scholarships?
column3: Students who are full-time may be granted full­- or half-­tuition scholarships for the academic year or semester. These awards provide for waiver of tuition and are subject to the maintenance of a high scholastic record in the Graduate School. Application is made to the student's department or program.

column2: How do I withdraw from a graduate program?
column3: Students who withdraw, who have their degree status discontinued, or whose time limit has expired and subsequently desire to resume their academic program, are required to apply for readmission. Readmission forms are available at the Graduate School's website.

column2: Can I take undergraduate courses as a grad student?
column3: A graduate student may petition to take undergraduate courses on a pass/fail basis. Such a petition must be approved by the end of the add period for the term the course is taken.

column2: What is the time limit for a Ph.D.?
column3: The Ph.D. must be completed within eight years of matriculation (enrollment after admission) or within seven years if the student entered with a master's degree in the same field.
column4: ["- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Doctoral Time Limits (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Years%20on%20leave%20do%20not%20count%20toward%20the%20time%20limit.)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Doctoral Time Limits (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Degree%20Requirements%20-%20Doctoral%20Time%20Limits%20The%20DNP%2C%20OTD%2C%20Ed.S.%2C%20and%20Ed.D%20degrees%20must%20be%20completed%20within%204%20years.)", "- Education (Ph.D.) - Education (Ph.D.) - Degree Requirements (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/education/education-phd/#:~:text=Education%20%28Ph.D.%29%20-%20Degree%20Requirements%20Students%20typically%20complete%2052%20to%2064%20hours%20in%20graduate%20coursework%20following%20their%20matriculation.)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Requirements - Residency (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/#:~:text=Requirements%20-%20Residency%20A%20minimum%20of%20three%20academic%20years%20of%20graduate%20study%20is%20required%20for%20the%20Ph.D%20degree.)", "- Education (Ph.D.) - Education (Ph.D.) - Degree Requirements (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/programs-study/education/education-phd/)", "- Degree Requirements - Degree Requirements - Ph.D. Requirements - Residency (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/degree-requirements/)"]

column2: What is a non-terminal master’s degree?
column3: Ph.D. students, with the approval of their department, may petition to earn a non-terminal master’s degree while completing the Ph. D.

column2: What is the process for appealing an academic dismissal?
column3: A student must submit a letter and supporting documents to the program chairperson and the dean of the Graduate School within ten (10) business days of the dismissal notification. The appeal should provide specific evidence, context, or mitigating factors that the student believes should be considered in reviewing the decision.

column2: How many transfer credits can be applied to a graduate degree?
column3: Students may request that a maximum of two courses, for up to 8 credits of graduate level coursework, from an accredited institution authorized to grant graduate degrees, be transferred to count toward their graduate program.

column2: Can I take a leave of absence?
column3: Unless a leave of absence is granted, graduate students enrolled in face to face programs are required to maintain continuous enrollment each semester of the academic year until their degree is formally awarded by registering for course credits, research, or continuing enrollment.

column2: Can I enroll in more than one degree?
column3: The Graduate School allows UNH students to pursue two degrees at UNH and count credits toward both degrees under the circumstances detailed below. Such credit will be granted only for graded coursework completed with a grade of "B-" or higher. Application of such credit toward a student's program for a second degree is subject to departmental recommendation and approval by the Graduate School.

column2: What is JTerm?
column3: The Master of Science in Project Management (MSLM) is a practice-oriented program ideal for managers who want to enhance their ability to plan and lead complex projects, motivate people, and deliver the desired business value associated with the project.

column3: Continuing Enrollment (GRAD 800) is for Master's students who are in residence and need to be full time but have already completed all course requirements, have previously registered for the maximum number of thesis or project credits. column2: How do I sibmity my committee?
column3: During the first semester, the student and advisor jointly select members of a guidance committee. A nomination form must be sent to the graduate school to officially appoint the committee membership. The Dissertation Committee will have at least 5 members: no more than 3 from any one NSB department, and 2 from other departments within UNH and/or from other doctoral-granting institutions.

column2: How many credits below B- lead to dismissal from the Graduate School?

column2: Who recommends and who decides a dismissal for lack of academic progress?
column3: A department chairperson or a graduate program coordinator, upon the recommendation of the appropriate faculty committee, may recommend dismissal for a student who is failing to make required academic progress in their program. This recommendation shall be forwarded in writing to the associate dean of the Graduate School with a copy to the affected student.

column2: Is a capstone required for master’s programs?
column3: All master’s degrees at UNH must include a capstone experience, with the exception of capstone courses, must be approved by a committee of at least two faculty members in the student's program and approved by the graduate program coordinator. All capstone experiences must be completed by the end of the final examination period of the graduation date for which the degree is to be conferred.

column2: What are the residency requirements for the Ph.D.?
column3: A minimum of three academic years of graduate study is required for the Ph.D. degree. Resident graduate work done at other universities may be counted toward the minimum requirement upon approval of the guidance committee and the Graduate School, but one full academic year must be in residence at the University of New Hampshire.

column2: What is Doctoral Research (999) and when must Ph.D. students register for it?
column3: Ph.D. students at candidacy must register for 999 each semester during the academic year, even if the minimum requirement has been met. Although Doctoral Research (999) is 0 credits, it grants full-time student status.

column2: When is a Ph.D. student advanced to candidacy and what form is required?
column3: Students are advanced to candidacy for the degree by the dean of the Graduate School upon recommendation of the graduate program coordinator after the student has passed the qualifying examination, met the language or proficiency requirements as are deemed desirable by the student's program, declared a topic for dissertation research, and fully formed their doctoral dissertation committee.

column2: What does an AF grade mean?
column3: A "AF" grade is assigned for failure to drop or complete a course. An AF grade is considered the same as an "F" grade. Grades Graduate Grading - Grades IA Grades: "IA" indicates "incomplete" in thesis credit, doctoral research, or other continuing courses of more than one semester.

column2: When is a CR grade used?
column3: A "CR" grade is assigned for successful completion, while an "F" grade was assigned for failure.  Grades Graduate Grading - Grades Credit/Fail Grades: Given in specific courses having no letter grades, such as thesis/dissertation, as well as other approved courses or seminars.

column2: What does an AU grade mean?
column3: The grade earned will replace the "IA" once the work has been completed. In the case of doctoral research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR". Prior semester IA grades will remain on the official transcript.

column2: What is the policy on course withdrawal (W) and its impact?
column3: Students who withdraw, for compelling nonacademic reasons, submit an approved petition to drop a course during the withdrawal period, a notation of "W" will be shown on the student's academic record. The specific withdrawal deadlines can be found on the UNH Academic Calendar.
column4: ["- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Graduate%20Grading%20-%20Grades%20W%20Grades%3A%20If%20a%20student%2C%20for%20compelling%20nonacademic%20reasons%2C%20submits%20an%20approved%20petition%20to%20drop%20a%20course%20during%20the%20withdrawal)", "- Registration - Registration - Non-registration - Withdrawal (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/#:~:text=Registration%20-%20Non-registration%20-%20Withdrawal%20A%20student%20may%20request%20to%20fully%20withdraw%20from%20their%20graduate%20degree%20program%20during%20any%20semester%20by%20obtaining%20a)", "- Registration - Registration - Continuous Registration Policy - Degree Status Discontinued (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/#:~:text=Registration%20-%20Continuous%20Registration%20Policy%20-%20Degree%20Status%20Discontinued%20Students%20who%20do%20not%20formally%20withdraw%20and%20do%20not%20register%20and%20pay%20for%20course)", "- Registration - Registration - Non-registration - Readmission (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/#:~:text=Students%20are%20not%20guaranteed%20readmission%20and%20may%20be%20evaluated%20in%20competition%20with%20current%20applicants%20to%20the%20program.)", "- Admissions - Admissions - Admission - Deferred Admission (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/admissions/#:~:text=Students%20who%20request%20a%20deferral%2C%20and%20who%20are%20not%20currently%20active%20in%20another%20degree%20program%2C%20are%20responsible%20for%20dropping%20any%20courses%20they%20may%20be%20currently)", "- Registration - Registration - Non-registration - Readmission (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/registration/)", "- Admissions - Admissions - Admission - Deferred Admission (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/general-information/admissions/)"]

column2: What happens when a graduate course is repeated?
column3: The cumulative grade-­point average of a course can be repeated for a maximum of 3 credits.

column2: How many times per year are graduate degrees conferred at UNH?
column3: Graduate degrees are conferred three times per year (September 1, December 31, and May) . The Graduate School allows UNH students to pursue two degrees at UNH and count credits toward both degrees under the circumstances detailed below. Such credit will be granted only for graded coursework completed with a grade of "B-" or higher.

column2: Do I have to file an intent to graduate?
column3: Students who do not file an intent-to-graduate will not have their degree awarded. column2: Who issues official transcripts and what is required before receiving a diploma?
column3: A student is required to satisfy University accounts before the Registrar will issue a diploma as evidence of work done at the University.

column2: What is an IA grade?
column3: The grade earned will replace the grade earned once the work has been completed. In the case of doctoral research, once the dissertation is deemed complete, only the final term of enrollment will be assigned a "CR". Prior semester "IA" grades will remain on the official transcript.
column4: ["- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=The%20grade%20earned%20will%20replace%20the%20%22IA%22%20once%20the%20work%20has%20been%20completed.)", "- Integrated Applied Mathematics (IAM) - Integrated Applied Mathematics (IAM) - IAM 999 - Doctoral Research (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/course-descriptions/iam/#:~:text=Integrated%20Applied%20Mathematics%20%28IAM%29%20-%20IAM%20999%20-%20Doctoral%20Research%20Grade%20Mode%3A%20Graduate%20Credit/Fail%20grading)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Graduate%20Grading%20-%20Grades%20Audit%20Grades%3A%20An%20%22AU%22%20grade%20is%20assigned%20for%20completion%20of%20courses%20for%20which%20an%20audit%20was%20granted.)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/#:~:text=Graduate%20Grading%20-%20Grades%20AF%20Grades%3A%20An%20%22AF%22%20grade%2C%20Administrative%20F%2C%20is%20assigned%20for%20failure%20to%20either%20drop%20or%20complete%20a%20course.)", "- Education (EDUC) - Education (EDUC) - EDUC 974 - Educational Administrative Internship (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/course-descriptions/educ/#:~:text=Education%20%28EDUC%29%20-%20EDUC%20974%20-%20Educational%20Administrative%20Internship%20Grade%20Mode%3A%20Graduate%20Credit/Fail%20grading)", "- Graduate Grading - Graduate Grading - Grades (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/academic-regulations-degree-requirements/grading/)", "- Education (EDUC) - Education (EDUC) - EDUC 974 - Educational Administrative Internship (https://catalog.unh.edu/graduate/course-descriptions/educ/)"]

column2: Can I do a dual degree?
column3: The Graduate School allows UNH students to pursue two degrees at UNH and count credits toward both degrees under the circumstances detailed below. Such credit will be granted only for graded coursework completed with a grade of "B-" or higher. Application of such credit toward a student's program for a second degree is subject to departmental recommendation and approval by the Graduate School.

column2: Can I appeal a dismissal?
column3: In extraordinary circumstances, the Dean may call the appeals panel back together or overturn the decision of the panel. Otherwise, decisions made by the panel are final and non-reviewable.

column2: How long do I have to complete my master’s degree?
column3: The time limit for graduate work for any master’s degree must normally be completed within four years from the date of matriculation (enrollment following admission) in the program.

column2: Do I need RCR training?
column3: The Graduate Council has mandated that all incoming Ph.D. students complete RCR training approved by the Graduate School by the end of their first semester. For more information, visit the RCR website.

column2: What is a non-terminal degree?
column3: The degree of doctor of education is a terminal doctoral degree that prepares students for careers in educational leadership. The program curriculum comprises courses in educational policy, law, budget management, research methods, and human resources, as well as a research-based capstone. Requirements for completion of the Ed.D.

column2: How do I apply to grad school?
column3: The first step toward applying to the program is to contact a faculty member whose research is in a topic that matches your interest in order to arrange support for your thesis or paper of publishable quality. Interested students must submit a full graduate application to the graduate school during their junior year.

column2: What is the application deadline?
column3: The deadline for admission and financial aid vary by program. These are updated on an annual basis and may be found on each of the program pages. column2: Does UNH offer student health insurance?
column3: The UNH Student Health Benefits Plan (SHBP) provides comprehensive, student-focused, primary medical care through a team approach. The clinical staff consists of board-certified physicians, nurse practitioners, nurses, and medical assistants who are committed to prevention and holistic care. Primary medical care is provided for a variety of common concerns.

column2: What is the difference between GRAD 800 and GRAD 900?
column3: The Continuing Enrollment Graduate School (GRAD) is for Master's students who are in residence and need to be full time but have already completed all course requirements, have previously registered for the maximum number of thesis or project credits. As this grants full-time status, students are also responsible for the full time mandatory fees.

column3: Several forms of financial assistance are available to graduate students through the Graduate School and individual departments, most of which are awarded for an academic year commencing in the fall.

column2: Where can I find information about assistantships?
column3: Students on full assistantships are involved in assistantship activities for 20 hours a week during the academic year. The workload for students on stipend only and hourly appointments is specified at the time of appointment. The load for students in both of these categories is less than 20 hours per week.

column2: How do I withdraw from the program?
column3: Students who are applying for readmission are required to pay an application fee plus, if readmitted, any accumulated continuing enrollment fees for the period during which they have been inactive. Students are not guaranteed readmission and may be evaluated in competition with current applicants to the program.

column2: Can I change my degree?
column3: Students who wish to pursue a degree program other than the one for which admission was originally granted must complete the appropriate application for a change of degree. This includes students enrolled in UNH master's programs who intend to pursue the Ph.D. in the same department in which they were admitted for the Master's degree.

column2: How long does it typically take to complete the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Students admitted from a UNH Bachelor’s degree program can complete the Accelerated Master's program in 12 months depending on the courses completed during their undergraduate program.

column2: How many total credits are required for the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.)?
column3: The M.S. in Biotech:IBMS is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and an Capstone experience (3-9 credits).

column2: What is the credit range for the Capstone Experience in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and an Capstone experience (3-9 credits).

column3: The M.S. in Biotech:IBMS is offered in traditional and accelerated formats, each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and the Capstone experience (3-9 credits).

column2: What is the purpose of the Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The Core Curriculum in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program will be able to: Form a core expertise in an area (or areas) of biotechnology (and allied fields) selected by the student, sufficient to conduct supervised research or other further work (such as industrial development) in that area.

column2: Who helps Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) students develop a curriculum plan?

column2: Can students begin the capstone before completing 9 credits in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The capstone will consist of one of the following: Capstone A , a research project in a UNH Manchester faculty member’s research laboratory (typically your Faculty Advisor); Capstone B, an internship or applied research experience in an industry setting (including the student’s current workplace if applicable); or, Capstone C , an industry co-op experience.

column2: What is the relationship between core courses and elective courses in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The program welcomes you to enroll in courses in other UNH colleges in order to complete your elective requirements. column2: What core knowledge areas will students master in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The Biotechnology:Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program will be able to: Form a core expertise in an area (or areas) of biotechnology (and allied fields) selected by the student, sufficient to conduct supervised research or other further work (such as industrial development) in that area.

column2: What laboratory skills will students develop in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The Biotechnology:Industrial and Biomedical Sciences program will be able to: Deploy important biotechnology industry-relevant transferrable job skills, such as clear communication, cooperation and relationship building, teamwork and conflict resolution, and creative problem-solving and strategic thinking.

column2: What legal and regulatory understanding is expected in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) focuses on the application of the biological and biochemical sciences, and particularly genetics, to the preparation of new and enhanced biomedical, industrial, agricultural, and environmental products.

column2: What capstone expectation exists in the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program?
column3: The capstone will consist of one of the following: Capstone A, a research project in a UNH Manchester faculty member’s research laboratory (typically your Faculty Advisor); Capstone B, an internship or applied research experience in an industry setting (including the student’s current workplace if applicable); or, Capstone C, an industry co-op experience.

column2: In the Biotechnology: Industrial and Biomedical Sciences (M.S.) program, how many hours of academic work does each credit typically represent?
column3: The M.S. in Biotech:IBMS is offered in traditional and accelerated formats each of which require students to complete 30 credits comprised of 4 Core Curriculum courses and a Graduate Biotech Seminar course (13 total credits), a series of Elective Courses (8-14 credits), and Capstone experience (3-9 credits).

column2: Who is the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) program designed for?
column3: Working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. column3: The M.S. in Cybersecurity Engineering gives you the technical skills and experience to meet that demand, preparing you to secure information, communications, networks and control systems for any organization. column2: What kind of theoretical knowledge is paired with practice in the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.)?
column3: Designed for working professionals and those with a strong interest in cybersecurity, the program combines in-class and online learning on how to develop, engineer and operate secure information systems. You will learn the theoretical underpinnings of information security and have opportunities to apply your knowledge and skills to real-world scenarios and authentic project experiences.

column2: How does the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) position graduates for organizational impact?
column3: The Cybersecurity Engineering program is able to identify, analyze and respond to the complex information security threats that are increasingly common in today's digital landscape. You'll learn skills in core and advanced information security, preparing you to develop, integrate and evaluate secure IT systems and services for any organization.

column2: According to the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) description, what three actions will students learn regarding secure information systems?
column3: Security is a key component of cybersecurity, and it's important to understand how best practices, standards, and organizational policy can help manage such measures.  Security Measures I Cybersecurity Policy & Risk Management (CPRM) - CPRM 830 - security measures I This course introduces common technological and organizational measures for cybersecurity, with a focus on protection concepts.

column2: Does the Cybersecurity Engineering (M.S.) requirements page describe a capstone or culminating experience?
column3: The Capstone project requires a minimum 30 graduate credits made up of nine core courses and culminating with a required capstone experience. column2: Does the IT (M.S.) program require an internship?
column3: Students are required to enroll in at least 1 credit of Internship Experience upon successful completion of nine credits in the program. COMP 891 , COMP 892 , or COMP 893 may be repeated for a maximum of 6 credits.

column2: Does the Information Technology (M.S.) offer flexibility for part-time students?
column3: The MS in Information Technology program is a professional graduate program in the applied and fast-changing field of Information Technology. The program prepares students for a career in IT or computing-related career and for advanced studies in a computing discipline.

column2: Does the Information Technology (M.S.) curriculum include both coursework and research?
column3: The MS in Information Technology program is a professional graduate program in the applied and fast-changing field of Information Technology. The program prepares students for a career in IT or computing-related career and for advanced studies in a computing discipline.

column2: What’s the difference between IA and IC grades for graduate students?
column3: The IAM Program offers a unique curriculum emphasizing advanced applied mathematical methods and high-performance computing. A Ph.D. candidate in IAM is expected to develop expertise in both applied and computational mathematics as well as one area of specialization (e.g., fluid dynamics, plasma physics and space physics, geoscience, dynamical systems, biophysics, etc.).

column2: What registration is required for graduate assistants to be considered full time?
column3: Students holding assistantship appointments are also considered full time and must register for a minimum of 6 credits, GRAD 900 Master's Continuing Research , or Doctoral Research (999).

column2: How is a master’s thesis committee formed at UNH?
column3: A master’s thesis committee is a committee composed of a regular member of the graduate faculty under whose direction it was written and two other members of the graduated faculty nominated by the department chairperson or graduate program coordinator and appointed by the dean of the Graduate School.

column2: How do I apply for a graduate certificate?
column3: Graduate certificate programs require the completion of at least 4 graduate courses for a minimum of 12 credits of graduate coursework (800- or 900-level courses) organized in a coherent and logical manner to provide knowledge and expertise relevant to a specific aspect of professional and/or personal development.

column2: Can I defer my admission offer?
column3: Admissions are limited and competition for admission may vary from year to year. Applicants who are denied admission may have their applications reconsidered only if they furnish significant additional material that was not available at the time of the original decision.

column2: How many years do I have to finish my master’s?
column3: The time limit for graduate work for any master's degree must normally be completed within four years from the date of matriculation (enrollment following admission) in the program.

column2: Where can I find information about graduate housing?
column3: The University will supply information about the employment of its graduates who have graduated from our degree and/or certificate programs. This information may be obtained upon request from the University's Advising and Career Center and is available by university, college, or school to current and prospective students.

column2: How do I submit my thesis?
column3: Students who are in a thesis program are required to conduct research and prepare a scholarly paper under the guidance of a faculty committee for submission to the Graduate School. Guidelines on the purpose, framework, and process for the thesis should be clearly articulated by each program.

column2: What are the mandatory fees for graduate assistants?
column3: Students on full assistantships are charged 50% of the full-time mandatory fees rate. Students on stipend only and hourly appointments are specified at the time of appointment. The workload for students in both of these categories is less than 20 hours per week.

column2: How do I apply for financial aid or scholarships?
column3: Students who are full-time may be granted full­- or half-­tuition scholarships for the academic year or semester. These awards provide for waiver of tuition and are subject to the maintenance of a high scholastic record in the Graduate School. Application deadlines for admission and financial aid vary by program.

column2: How do I withdraw from a graduate program?
column3: Students who are applying for readmission are required to pay an application fee plus, if readmitted, any accumulated continuing enrollment fees for the period during which they have been inactive. Students are not guaranteed readmission and may be evaluated in competition with current applicants to the program.

column2: Can I take undergraduate courses as a grad student?
column3: A graduate student may petition to take undergraduate courses on a pass/fail basis. Such a petition must be approved by the end of the add period for the term the course is taken.

column2: What is the time limit for a Ph.D.?
column3: The Ph.D. must be completed within eight years of matriculation (enrollment after admission) or within seven years if the student entered with a master's degree in the same field.

column2: What is the process for appealing an academic dismissal?
column3: A student must submit a letter and supporting documents to the program chairperson and the dean of the Graduate School within ten (10) business days of the dismissal notification. The application should provide specific evidence, context, or mitigating factors that the student believes should be considered in reviewing the decision.

column2: How many transfer credits can be applied to a graduate degree?
column3: Students may request that a maximum of two courses, for up to 8 credits of graduate level coursework, from an accredited institution authorized to grant graduate degrees, be transferred to count toward their graduate program.

column2: Can I take a leave of absence?
column3: Students who, because of extenuating circumstances, are unable to pursue their graduate program may request a leave of absence for a maximum of one calendar year. Such circumstances may include medical reasons, military obligation, family emergencies, or hardship.

column2: What is a guidance committee?
column3: A guidance committee should be appointed for the student by the dean of the Graduate School upon recommendation of the advisor and graduate coordinator. This committee assists in outlining the student's course of study and may specify individual coursework requirements. The guidance committee administers the qualifying examination.

column2: Can I take a course Pass/Fail?
column3: Graduate courses cannot be taken pass/fail. A graduate student may petition to take undergraduate courses on a pass/ferail basis. Such a petition must be approved by the end of the add period for the term the course is taken.

column2: Can I appeal a grade?
column3: Generally, dismissed students will not be able to continue in classes pending the outcome of the appeal, but the program chairperson may make a final decision regarding whether to uphold or overturn the dismissal, normally within 20 days of receiving the appeal.

column2: Can I enroll in more than one degree?
column3: The Graduate School allows UNH students to pursue two degrees at UNH and count credits toward both degrees under the circumstances detailed below. Such credit will be granted only for graded coursework completed with a grade of "B-" or higher. Application of such credit toward a student's program for a second degree is subject to departmental recommendation and approval by the Graduate School.

column2: What is GRAD 800?
column3: Students registered for  Continuing Enrollment Graduate School (GRAD) - GRAD 800 - Continuing Inrollment All continuing graduate students who are not enrolled for course credits, thesis credits, Doctoral Research (999) or Master's Continuing Research (Grad 891 - National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship Preparation This course is designed to enable students to receive information, guidance, and support in applying for the National Science Fund (NSF) Graduate Research Fellow program (GRFP).

column2: What is GRAD 900?
column3: The National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship program (GRFP) is for Master's students who are in residence and need to be full time but have already completed all course requirements, have previously registered for the maximum number of thesis or project credits. As this grants full-time status, students are also responsible for the full time mandatory fees.

column2: How do I sibmity my committee?
column3: During the first semester, the student and advisor jointly select members of a guidance committee. A nomination form must be sent to the graduate school to officially appoint the committee membership. The guidance committee consists of 3-5 members and is responsible for approving the proposal and oversees the qualifying examination.

column2: What is the difference between an IA and an IC grade?
column3: The IAM program offers a unique curriculum emphasizing advanced applied mathematical methods and high-performance computing. A Ph.D. candidate in IAM is expected to develop expertise in both applied and computational mathematics as well as one area of specialization (e.g., fluid dynamics, plasma physics and space physics, geoscience, dynamical systems, biophysics, etc.).
